In short, is the game good?  Yes, yes and triple yes.   Is it worth my time and money?  Yes. Considering how cheap The Binding of Isaac + Wrath of The Lamb is, there really isn't an excuse *not to buy it*. You will most definitely sink a lot of time into the game and you will have fun.   Is this game for anyone?  Considering the quasi-random nature of the gameplay, some of the runs you will do will be a walk in the park, while others may be pure nightmare. If you do not enjoy dying and losing progress over and over, this game may not be for you. If that isn't the case, go for it.   Linear, open-world or something else?  Something else. No two runs will ever be the same. The room layout, boss encounters, items you will get and overall difficulty are mainly dictated at random. While the set pieces themselves do not change properties that much (maybe aside meeting stronger, 'champion' versions of monsters), the way it's all set up makes every run a fresh, new experience.   Gameplay mechanics, gimmicks?  You run around rooms in a 2D top-down view. You collect items that change the way your character behaves (make you faster, slower, stronger, shoot more, shoot faster, etc.). Items aren't really a necessity but without them the run may be near-impossible to do (considering the later levels where enemies deal twice as much damage and bosses have a really high level of health).   Graphical aesthetics, set pieces and world design?  The game has a very dark and cartoony look, in some places even grotesque. Vibrant colours and simplified forms meet with dark and horror-like rooms filled with hideous monsters that look like something out of Lovecraft's or Kafka's work. All of it feels well put together and it shows that a lot of thought was put into the overall design.   Audio design and soundtrack?  Excellent choices in sound effects as well as in the music soundtrack. Church-like ambiency clashing with hard guitar riffs and sounds of all kinds of hideous monsters go well together, creating an dark atmosphere that is immersive and enjoyable.   Plot, story?  Quite unique. The top layer of the story is simple, referring to real world topics such as fundamentalism, parenting and escapism. For those brave enough to take up the challenge, the game rewards the player with a deeper meaning to the story and a bit clearer undestanding what is really going on.   How does the game run?  I have played and 'finished' (that is, got the last ending, since the game never really ends) the game on my 5 year old PC (Dual Core 2.66GHz, 2GB RAM, nVidia GeForce 9600GT) and it ran without much problems in fullscreen mode and on the 'Auto' settings. There were instances where I was experiencing severe framerate issues due to the way the game was programmed (Flash has terrible issues when drawing lots of stuff at once, since it's all vector-based). This was happening in more 'crowded' rooms such as bullet hell-esque boss fights. Changing the settings to 'Low' eliminated the problem for me completely. So, if you have a similar PC to mine, just set the game to Low or Medium and it should be fine in fullscreen mode. If you have a newer machine, expect way better results.   Any details, character, motif, etc. you particularly liked?  Yes, the D6 dice. Brings a completely new meta-game into your runs and adds a layer of careful planning.   Anything you didn't like?  Yes. First of all, Flash. The game could run way better if it wasn't using Flash as a rendering engine. Then again, The Binding of Isaac was meant to be a side-project so it's understandable that the creators didn't have the time and/or resources to write a fully functional, brand new, custom engine from the ground up. Although that will probably change since The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is set to come out not too far from now. Second, no controller support. While that's not a dealbreaker, it could've been easily patched in. Instead we see a 'recomendation', in the options menu, to use Joy2Key. That's not a very professional way of doing things. On the other-hand, the game can be played without problems using a keyboard, so it's not a terribly big issue. Finally, lack of item descriptions. I understand that there's an element of learning when picking up items but a short description of what item does what would be nice. Instead, new players (along with myself) had to use the wiki to check if they want to really pick up this or that item.   Final score?  I give The Binding of Isaac (+The Wrath of The Lamb) a Mom's Knife out of 5.

I would heartily recommend The Binding of Isaac to anyone who isn't too squeamish. While the artstyle is very cartoony it still has some disturbing imagery and grotesque designs. That being said, this childlike portayal of such menacing sights offers a very interesting visual presentation for the game.  The proof, however, lies in the playing. This begs the question of how well The Binding of Isaac's gameplay holds up. For being such a simple idea initially to shoot baddies while avoiding being shot yourself a surprising amount of complexity is added with its varied item combinations. One game session you may find yourself becoming a flying demon spitting unforgiving lasers from hell, while in the next you may be stuck peeing on enemies as your only form of self defence. The game also does an okay job of ramping up the difficulty as the player progresses.  In conclusion, give this game a spin if you can spare the money and you can handle its graphical style. You may also want to consider picking up the expansion Wrath of the Lamb, it makes it even better.

The Binding of Isaac is a great game. It is very replayable and addictive, and the random elements make every run a little bit different. Wrath of the Lamb only expands on this, and makes the game even better than it was before. I would give it a positive rating...  If not for Flash.  Flash ruins this game. The performance is about as stable and reliable as a one-legged mountain goat, and the game is rife with bugs. The only graphical settings are the nondescript 'Low, Medium, High', and the game is locked to a certain resolution. There is no controller support, and your progress gets wiped if you clear Flash memory. If you want to play Isaac, just wait for Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, a remake that not only gets rid of Flash but also expands on the game.

The Binding of Isaac is a good way to waste time. Each level is randomly generated and death is permanent; you never know what's in store for you when you start it up. Though dying sucks, you'll still likely feel a sense of achievement as you go deeper into the story and unlock more content. I highly recommend having the wiki open while playing, as there are a ton of items with different and obscure effects. I'd also like to suggest playing the base game for a bit before activating the Wrath of the Lamb DLC. It's a fun and compelling game that's just hard enough to make you want to give it another shot, over and over again. Once you've completed some achievements, you can even change youre starting character. The soundtrack is astounding and the enemies are creative. 10/10 Because 'The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth' is coming out soon, it's probably wise to wait and see if that's any good before buying this. It's supposed to have a lot of new features. The fact that Rebirth exists doesn't make this game any less good but if you can only buy one, you should know you're getting the best.

Not only is the game based on how well you can adapt to certain encounters with what you have, but it's also based on luck. The layout of the area changes each time you play, so while you may get an awful/useless item and immediately be swarmed with enemies in the next room the first time around, you could get extremely lucky and find consecutive unlocked doors with loot inside that will make the next few floors a cakewalk. It's a very good game, and it can get frustrating at times, yes, but it's very enjoyable to play. If you're alright with creepy, disfigured monsters hanging around in the basement, that is.

The Binding of Isaac Game Review  The binding of Isaac is a indie rogue-like platformer game about a child called Isaac and his crazy religious mother. It is a game filled with secrets and unlockable characters and items with 2 DLC packs. After playing The Binding of Isaac for a few hours I realised there was a reason so many people described the game as “Unforgiving” and “disturbing”, It’s because its filled with satanic references, blood and gore. Not only that but The Binding of Isaac is incredibly difficult, only after my first 10 tries was I able to kill mom once. My favourite thing about The Binding of Isaac would have to be the game breaking aspect. By game breaking I mean there are some incompatible items in the game which cause you to have infinite health or can help you to get every item in the game. There is actually a massive part of the community that has dedicated itself to finding game breaking glitches that can make them extremely overpowered; some of these people have broken the game to the extent that a single attack on any boss will kill them instantly.  Controls and Gameplay  The controls to The Binding of Isaac are basic. WASD to move and your arrow keys to direct your attack. You move around the basement from room to room, each room containing something different. There are normal rooms which contain enemies, gold rooms which contain power up items that will impact your speed, damage, health and can sometimes impact you negatively.  You first meet Isaac and his mother in the loading screen for the game which describes their lives as being happy until she hears a voice from above. The voice of god tells her to kill Isaac and Isaac, hearing this, flees into the houses basement to get away from his homicidal mother which is when the games main menu loads. The game is about Isaac making his way through the basement to eventually reach and kill the boss, Mom. As you make your way through the basement you will encounter multiple different types of enemies (foetuses, pinworms, embryos, flaming headless monsters and lots of bugs) which will all try to kill you.  Graphics and Sound  The graphics for The Binding of Isaac were made to have a retro feel to them. They have options for the in game detail which affects the rooms you enter. High detail means there will be cobwebs and blood on the walls while low detail will give you none of that. The detail setting also affects the pixels in game so setting it to low will give you a very fuzzy effect while high makes it look HD in comparison.  The music in The Binding of Isaac is very varied. The music changes depending on the floor and room you are on/in. The music keeps you focused while playing and can help you to know what type of room or floor you are on. The sounds in The Binding of Isaac are very eerie to say the least. The squishing noises when you kill monsters and the screaming from bosses I found to be very unsettling when I was playing and actually impacted on my performance when I was playing.   Replayability and Multiplayer  The Binding of Isaac is literally the most replayable game I have ever played; this is because of how unforgiving the game and how interesting the storyline is. With over 341 items and 178 secrets in the game you must replay constantly to finish the game with everything unlocked.  There has never been a official multiplayer feature for The Binding of Isaac however the great community surrounding it has created a few multiplayer mods for people to use. This let you play 2 players with you and another person on the same keyboard and you can both move around and shoot and fight enemies. Although the multiplayer mod is good, I think it ruins the game as there is no balancing aspect to the mod meaning there is now2 players but the same amount of bosses and enemies.  To Conclude  I found The Binding of Isaac to be a ridiculously good indie game. The complexity of the story line and the references to religion surprised me and definitely made me enjoy the game a lot more. At only £4.00 this game is definitely one I would pick up off the steam store, especially as it is now one of my most played games and it’s one of the cheapest I own, this game practically pays for itself in minutes. The games DLC is also worth getting as it doubles the amount of content that is already inside this jam packed game, it adds characters, items, floors, monsters and more difficult bosses. So to give this game a rating I would have to give it a: • Easy to learn controls ✓ • Gameplay ✓ • Graphics ✓ • Sound/Music ✓ • Replayable ✓ • Multiplayer X RATED 5/6

This game is a complete surprise. The graphics are minimalistic, the sounds are average, and the gameplay quite retro zelda like. But for some reason, because it's a short game that can only take you 30 minutes to beat in one playthrough it's not about the one playthrough. Each time through you will find different random upgrades or weapons, different monsters, different bosses and of course different loot. This is by no means an easy game. Might get frustrating, but for some reason I keep coming back to it. This game is fun!

It's dirt cheap during any sale and it is as gold as everything else Team Meat has managed to churn out. If you are curious what you are getting into it, it's something strangely familiar and incredibly well made. It is basically a top down shooter reminescent of old Zelda games (my favorite kind) with roguelike elements and some twisted humor.  *On a side note: buy the DLC, I don't need to add why, its everything you love topped with more of what you love.  Roguelikes have been making a resurgence lately as part of the revisionist mantra of 'real gamers like hardcore challenges'. Which is all well and good, sure I like to be challenged in certain ways, but I definitely like to relax too. More importantly it's not just any challenge that gamers should clamor for, it's the good kind, the fair kind. Team Meat has this down perfectly. When ever you die in one of their games it's not a question of a flaw in the game's design, an enemy that is overpower, or an impossible obstacle, the only the wrong is you. The game has a simple set of mechanics and some secrets in gameplay that you can and should figure out on your own. When you lose in this game you should feel that welcome brand of shame that says 'I should've known better'. This game isn't trying to fool, you know what you are playing and you know what you should've done.  The real draw from a game that is continously killing you, besides the superb gamplay, is the sense of progress and reward. There is a plethora of secrets to be found in The Binding of Isaac, all unlocked in a variety of ways and adding to the gameplay. The game starts with Isaac, there are more characters to unlock later, shooting tears and running around naked. From defeating bosses, random chests, or treasure rooms, Isaac unlocks various items that alter his abilities. Most of the abilities are passive and stack, and some are useable abilities like cards or a cat's head. These items are all random ( a treasure may net you a spiffy spider upgrade to your tears or just a teleporter) and the levels are procedurally generated. On top of all the game altering the items can do, they also change your character's appearance into something that is usually atrocious and hilarious.  The Binding of Isaac will kill you a lot (and not in the Dark Souls way where you can still get something back and respawn from the last campfire), but you will never feel like it was a waste. I've had some two minute sessions of this game that netted me a new secret item, and there is always something to unlock in The Binding of Isaac. After dying so many times you will get better, and then you will still keep dying, but you'll enjoy it.

The Binding of Isaac is perhaps one of the most poorly coded games I've had the pleasure of playing and, despite that, I would heartily recommend it over most AAA titles.  The game operates on the premise that your mother is out to kill you and you are trying to escape horrible, horrible death. So, you jump into the basement. This is where the game earns its keep. Isaac is a 2-D Top Down Shooter with randomly generated levels where death means the end of a run and your success can largely depend on the luck of the items randomly generated within those levels.  The game is pretty much about avoiding damage while clearing rooms while finding upgrades so you can win the game. It rarely approaches the level of bullethell dodging, but mostly just relies on sheer variety of enemies & bosses to kill you, whether through that one bullet you walked into or the one fly who you ignored who rammed into you. Still, it's pretty much all dodgeable at the end of the day, with a few unfair moments. Still, that's what makes this roguelike so much fun.

The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game in which you play as a child traversing through randomly generated levels with the goal of stopping your mom from killing you. There is a large number of items that also randomly generate each playthrough that you can use to aid in your adventure. As you play the game, you unlock secrets and additional items to use in future playthroughs.  With the Wrath of Lamb DLC, there are additional items, a new item type, floors (as opposed to levels), and bosses. The DLC also introduces challenges that limit (or otherwise challenge) you, which upon completion unlock new items for the main game. If you are considering buying The Binding of Isaac, I highly recommend also purchasing the Wrath of Lamb DLC.  This game is heavy on both skill and luck. You will die a lot when you start playing the game. It will take many, many attempts to defeat the first final boss for the first time. As you complete playthroughs and unlock secrets, you will gain skill and new items that may help you in future playthroughs.   The biggest issue with this game is that the framerate drops when a lot of tears (projectiles) or flashing enemies (flies), probably due to using the Flash engine. This is highly noticeable while playing the game, especially upon completing two certain bosses. It took me at least 10 in-game hours to get used to the wild framerate. Another issue is that the game may almost crash when it tries generating certain floors, which can be resolved by waiting for the program to respond even if the option to close the problem comes up.  If you are interested in the game and would probably play this game a lot (tens and tens of hours), I would recommend purchasing The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, which is a remake of the original game and DLC. A lot of new items, challenges, characters, enemies, and bosses are introduced. The art style is better (imo), the mechanics are better due to the change in game engine, and the game runs much more smoothly. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth costs $14.99 normally. It is up to you on which you purchase if you want to.

The Binding of Isaac is a frustratingly-fun and challenging zelda-style rogue-lite, created by Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy) and Florian Himsl (Coil, The C-Word).  The game features a ton of variables in the forms of characters, bosses, items, and power-ups, all of which can alter how much you progress throughout the game.  With hilarious (and sometimes creepy) references to faith, religion, human ethics, and biology, Isaac is a delicious slice of blasphemy, served with a sour lemon.
This game is very replayable, and extremely fun. You should definitely play it.

Little late to the party, but I want to try out this new 'Steam Reviews' thing by reviewing The Binding of Isaac. Contrary to popular belief, The Binding of Isaac is not hard, more, unforgiving. Many will be turned off by the nature of reviews stating it is hard and requires much skill. I find it, however, more unforgiving than 'hard'. Yes, there is a difference.  'Well, what do you mean?', says random bystander awed by hearing other's analysis being gone against.   Well, you see, anyone who has played The Binding of Isaac can tell you it is a randomly generated game. This aspect gives it a very nice value of replayablility. Luck is a key factor in this generation, so you want a 'lucky' run. However, anyone with a lot of skill CAN beat this game with crappy items. You see, the challenge does not stem from its risky 1 life gameplay style, as you can restart and get better items, possibly a 1-up to give you another life, the challenge comes from the random generation and ♥♥♥♥ loads of projectiles. However, you can master this game. Like I said before, you can use your skill to beat this game with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ items. Some strategies such as Secret Room guessing, and knowing how to avoid certain items really helps a lot. The secret to beating this game is to be immersed in its content and variables.    'So what? You can beat the game if you take into consideration your knowledge of this game. What makes you think more people will buy it?', says a bystander who keeps getting owned by Peeps.   Well, you see, The Binding of Isaac has had a reputation for being an infamously hard game. The real ironic thing is, people can beat it in their first few runs. Then more content unlocks, and they gradually keep becoming better at the game. The game is not hard, its just a thing you can't plow through. I hope this will help people off put by the game's reputation as 'hard' join in on the fun. I'm sorry this isn't much of a review, I'm really busy (With doing nothing) and I can't be bothered to write a full review. Though to truly know this game, you must play it yourself. Bye, and I hope to see you all again in 2014.

Story: A bit dark and filled with jabs at religion. That doesn't bother me, but the game is definitly not appropriate for a younger audience and those who don't take religion jokes lightly. Also, some of the bosses/mobs are a bit gruesome and distrubing (but I dont mind!!).  The game without the DLC has about 7 levels, takes me about an hour (on a good run) to beat the game. Considering that I have more than 20 hours into this game and have only beaten it 5 times :C. The trick to this game is that death is permanent for your current playthrough. Once you die you have to restart at the beginning and pray for good items.   IF you aren't accustomed to the perma-death scenario I don't reccommend this game. I enjoy it purely because of the flexibility of the levels and the ever-changing drops.   This game is a great game and has a good price imo.

tldr:  6/10  - A rather mediocre top-down rogue action game with dark humor. I keep returning to it when I have a minute and I don't feel like doing anything complex or time consuming. Would absolutely skip if it wasn't on sale. Still very recommended at a reasonable price if you're looking for a simple casual game which is easy to get into.   too long part:  STORY - ?/10  You're playing as Isaac - a little kid whose mom is nuts and wants to kill him, so he descends through a trap door in his room to fight his way through creepy places with creepy monsters in them.    GAMEPLAY - 6/10  - Simple but hard to master controls. Depends on anyones taste.  - The game has its own economy and a SH*TLOAD of upgrades, active skills and consumables to be discovered. Each upgrade and skill is very interesting and fun to mess around with. While it's tempting to google what does what, it's way better fun to just pick something up and see what it does.  - Levels are randomized and there is a lot of various monsters and bosses to spice things up. You won't play the game the same way twice. From this point of view the game offers infinite replayability, but...  - The fact that everything is so heavily randomized prevents you from forming any sort of your own strategy. You just dive in and keep going until you win or die. Over time, this reduces the cool variety to the point where you're doing the same thing over and over again and it's only a liiiiiiiittle bit different because of some dice roll.   - There is not much persistence to keep you returning for more. There are few unlockable characters and mandatory achievements but upgrades and skills are limited for each run where you find them. While it's nice to know that the game doesn't have you on a leash trying to unlock everything, it doesn't really motivate you to achieve anything when you start from zero every single time.

It wasnt untill i didnt play it for about a week after my first time that i started to feel an urge to play it again ( it doesnt help that i was watching a lot of streams of a guy who played it a lot) and this time when i went back to the game i found my self enjoying the game, yeah i was still dieing a hella load ( i think i had around 40 deaths before i killed moms foot for the first time) but i wasnt raging about it, i was just thinking ' huh so thats what this little bugger does well imma getcha next time mister' and with the randomness of the items and the lackj of explination of what they do, i felt my self enjoying finding new items and figuring out what they do on my own, like an adventure, it was a sad day when i knew what all the items and trinkets and cards did. For those who are checking this game out because of rebirth i highly recommend you get this game and play it first, it is a great way to get the feel how the game plays and what it was like before we got them fancy pancy 16 bit graphics  Reveiw word of the day : Randomness

Isaac and his Mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself, drawing pictures and playing with his toys,  as his Mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple, and they were both happy. That was, until the day Isaac's Mom heard a voice, from above. 'Your son has become corrupted by sin! He needs to be saved!' 'I will do my best to save him, my Lord,' Isaac's Mother replied,  rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. Again, the voice called to her: 'Isaac's soul is still corrupt! He needs to be cut off from all that is evil, and confess his sins!' 'I will follow your instructions, Lord! I have faith in thee!' Isaac's Mother replied, as she locked Isaac away in his room, away from all the evils of the world. One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her: 'You have done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me! To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you.' 'Yes lord. Anything!' Isaac's mother begged. 'To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room, and end his life, as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else.' 'Yes, Lord,' she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the Basement, hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door,  and threw himself down, into the unknown depths below.  And thus begins one of the best games I've ever played, on Steam or otherwise. In this game you play as Isaac (or one of 6 other characters who may or may not also be Isaac in different costumes, depending on your interpretation of the endings) and go through randomized floors of the Basement (and the caves, and depths, and maybe even beyond!), collecting all sorts of weird/gross powerups to eventually face-off your Mother. Even if you've played Rebirth, I'd recommend you pick this up, if only just to see where it all began. It doesn't run perfectly (since it was programmed in Flash it's capped at 30FPS, but if you're on a toaster like me, that might be more than you get on rebirth! The soundtrack is superb (and personally better than rebirth's soundtrack IMO), and the graphics just kind of work (it looks like it's all part of Isaac's drawings, which according to the first ending, it is) Pros: -Harder than Rebirth (due to mechanics changes and a lack of SUPER op items that aren't extremely rare to compensate for their power) -10/10 soundtrack (even just opening it up today i found myself subconsiously humming the title screen music!) -Spooky, but in a good way (ie subtlety, and not hamfisted jumpscares) -Replayability (especially with the new 'Eternal Edition' update, I still haven't been able to beat some of those new bosses)  Neutral: -Different styled boss fights than Rebirth (while Rebirth has a lot of bullet hell-type fights, BoI has more mechanical fights, for example, instead of shooting bullet hell patterns like in Rebirth, the 'true' final boss will shoot at you only when you shoot, matching your fire rate, and some bosses like Carrion Queen are more about dodging the ground hazards while making sure to hit her weak point. Some people may prefer it, some may not, it's mostly a matter of personal preference)  Cons: -Fewer item synergies than Rebirth (Brimstone doesn't really synergize with anything aside from generic tear effects, Mom's Knife SORTA works with Spoon Bender and other similar effects i can't remember the name of in that the knife sorta wiggles in the direction of enemies, but mostly just keeps its same trajectory) -Lower framerate  -No controller support (unless you use Joy2Key)  One thing to keep in mind if you havent played it before, is that Wrath of the Lamb actually makes the game harder (by giving you a random chance to get alternate, harder versions of floors, and various curses that can help/hinder you), so if you're playing for the first time, you may not want to get the DLC right away, at least not until you've beaten the game a few times to unlock stuff. Also, you won't want hard mode on unless you're experienced with this game. Normal mode in this is equivalent to hard mode in Rebirth, so it's already decently hard.  Overall i definitely recommend this, you basically have no excuse not to pick this up if it's on sale because the price gets pretty low, and if you're like me you'll probably end up with a ton of time in this game (ignore my steam played stats, a lot of my progress was offline or using SpiderMod/Community Remix mod, which is why i'm missing a few achievements and still have platinum god)

Another beautifully composed game by Team Meat (Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes), a small independent developer who also created top hit Super Meat Boy. The Binding of Isaac strikes a resemblance to the original Legend of Zelda exploration esque gameplay through caves and dungeons, except in this title the main character (and arguable protagonist) Isaac ventures through his basement trying to escape his mother who is asked by the voice of God to make a sacrifice to prove her faith. The game implements great gameplay mechanics (which adapt to your style of progressing through the game to continuously increase the games difficulty), clever visuals, and a great plot to create an amazing atmosphere in a must have PC title.

The binding of Issac is one of those odd adventure games that combine a dark atmosphere with loads of combinations of items. a great side-scroller, and an investment in terms of its affordable price. I strongly recommend this game for its great ability to not become stale and provide hours of enjoyment in the vast quantities of enemies and items. A bit of dark humor also adds to the effect of this game to convey the message of a little boy trapped in a basement, on the run from his mother.

Binding of Isaac is a great example of a well-executed indie title that marries interestingly odd and obscure art and story references with engaging twitch-reflex gameplay. It's essentially a twin-stick shooter with power ups set in an unique dungeon environment. It has numerous rogue-like elements as well.   It's lacking resolutions higher than 720P, and when in Windowed mode it plays in a 4:3 square that looks fairly small on a 1080 screen. While in fullscreen mode, you cannot access the Steam overlay.   Other than few minor gripes listed above, this is a fun little rogue-like twin-stick-style adventure shooter set in a level-by-level dungeon design.

Run, Fight, Die, Repeat!   In a few words, this would be the game. It's a weird rogue like, quite addictive little game. It's one of the few games where getting an achievement actually helps in-game, the majority of them are unlocking new items, items that you might or might not need in your 'dungeon' exploring. Filled with a variety of items, which give you new powers and new aesthetics as well, every time getting randomized, one gameplay in 100 isn't even nearly the same, despite having the same levels, the maps and items are always random, but you could slowly but surly start figuring out some patterns, despite having a minimalistic tutorial at the start, you will be on your own after room 1. The whole game is a combination of LUCK and SKILL, both of them which are raised by EXPERIENCE (actually playing and replaying the game), it also involves some currency/item management and some though decisions, despite the lack of an actual inventory, you will gamble your way to the top or you will play it safe, the decision is yours.  WARNING: The game uses flash, not just once it happened to me that the game would crash due to high number of powerups/items picked up during the gameplay, resulting to a laggy/crashy gameplay. I played it a while ago, I heard of an upcoming new version, not sure if they updated or fixed the current one.  In rest, nothing bad that I could say about it, except that you will probably die a lot and it has good ambiental music.

note: I played this mostly offline, and have put considerably more than 4 hours into it.  I know it's not a popular opinion, but I really don't like the Binding of Isaac. There are a lot of things to like about it, most notably the wonderfully grotesque design, but I personally hate the core mechanics. I really really tried to love it (largely because it was a game that was easy to play on the bus), but eventually gave up.  Ok, so Binding of Isaac is a rogue-like, so we already know you're going to be dying and restarting a lot. That doesn't bother me. What does bother me is that you don't get better with each subsequent death. There's no lineage system or inventory hold over that helps you make a little more progress with each new game, you are just literally starting from scratch each time. And the controls are not complicated, so there isn't even an element of mastering the game's mechanics as progression.  And then there's other major design decision that I hate, the complete randomness. Procedurally generated games can be a ton of fun and help to keep things interesting, but your success in each run of this game is largely decided before you even leave the first room. The enemies being random is great, it keeps things from being rote. However, the power-ups being random is a huge problem because of the disparity between them. Power-ups can be utterly worthless, or god-tier, and you never know what you're going to go get. But because your previous attempts don't have any impact, you're relying entirely on the much necessary power-ups, which are sometimes just going to be useless.  One of my best runs was actually one of my first. In one of the first rooms I picked up a power-up that just devastated every enemy I came across. I've never been that lucky again. I enjoy challenging games, but there needs to be some sort of progression either through leveling or mastery of the mechanics, and Binding of Isaac has neither. There are of course going to be minor improvements to how you play, but for the most part, your 100th attempt has just as much chance of success as your 2nd attempt, and it's going to be based on what procedural roll you got. While this clearly doesn't deter most people, I find it to be an uninteresting set of mechanics that generally lead to wasting time on a run that was doomed to fail.

Exploring dark dungeons to escape your homicidal religious-freak mother, while fighting the forces of evil with your tears (among other fluids). That’s what The Binding of Isaac is about. The premise is simple and the gameplay is straightforward. The real fun comes from randomly generated dungeons and collecting transmogrifying upgrades. Every play through is a different experience. So far, this game has given me the most replayability value of all time. The maps and monsters are all randomly generated in each play, so even though the experience is similar each time, it is always a bit different on each play. The myriad of achievements allows for countless goals for those who like to complete tasks, and it is always fun to see what kinds of monsters and item combinations you can work with next for those who enjoy seeing the possibilities of a game. The graphics are dorky, gross, and simplistic, but I think that is part of the appeal for a McMillen game. Also, though the story with Isaac and his Mother is not exactly the most emphatic or traditionally presented part of the game, or what really keeps a person playing it (I imagine), it definitely adds a boost in character to the game and really opens a lot to think on if one decides they feel like doing so.  TLDR; play it. Its pretty awesome.

This game is stylish, dark, mean, and *hard*. The good kind of hard, where your skill and practice *pay off*. Expect to die, a lot, but keep at it--some day, you'll rise to the occasion, and the Depths that were once a nightmare you couldn't imagine getting through alive will be just another level, even while the game's difficulty level gradually increases as you complete in-game challenges and stronger enemies start showing up earlier and earlier. Not to mention the long, long list of little accomplishments that will unlock some new plaything for future dungeons. This is easily one of the best uses for a five-spot (or less, some days--seriously, I've bought sodas more expensive than what this game will cost you during a good sale) you will ever find.

As someone who has not put a great amount of hours into the game, my review comes with some understandable questioning. However, I still feel as though I have a good feel of the game already, going through many different playthroughs until I finally reached the point where I had the power to beat the final boss and the second final boss in the second playthrough. With that in mind, I find myself going through spurts of loving this game to pieces, playing it bit by bit and getting better as time goes by, collecting more and more items as my personal list of achievements grows. With that in mind, The Binding of Issac more than delivers on its content for the price of 5 dollars (plus seven if you get the incredibly fun 'Wrath of the Lamb' DLC). The game runs as an overhead shooter that drops you in the middle of a basement of horrors, pitting you against enemy after enemy as you struggle to survive against the different waves. At its very core the game is very simple: Kill the enemies with your weapon of choice while also avoiding the enemies with WASD at the same time. Once you are able to grasp the difficulty, it makes this game a very rewarding experience. But the true gold of the game shines through as you realize that there is a great deal of items available. In fact, there are so many items available that it makes for a different experience every time you play the game. Add the randomly generated dungeons and enemies throughout the game and you get to the point where you find yourself with an entirely different experience each time you play through the game. That being said, the game is not for those who are easily frustrated, as you will find yourself playing through it multiple times before you even get close to your desired goal. Despite that fact, I find the game well worth the seven dollars it is sold for.

For those of you that still haven't played this game, I strongly recommend you check it out. Of all of the games I have on Steam this is the game I most consistantly come back to. You play as Isaac a young boy who lives with his Christian mother, however one day your mother hears the voice of God telling her to kill her son as a sacrifice to prove her loyalty. The game definitely gives that creepy vibe of religious fanaticism. As far as gameplay it is very simply you move around with WASD and shoot your tears at enemies with the arrow keys. If is very simple but very elegant gameplay that takes very obviously after the original Legend of Zelda game. The difference is that Isaac is a rouge-like meaning that you play every run with permadeath, as soon as you die you have to restart and even cooler with the wide selection of items no two runs feel the same. You could get an absurdly powerful item such as brimstone or mom's knife to start off your run, conversely you might get something as awkward as lemon mishap. If you are a fan of randomly generated levels and runs that are different every time then Isaac is definitley worth checking out. Though just be forewarned of the messed up nature of the game. If you are alright with creepy, and downright ridiculous enemies, bosses and story then Isaac gives you a game with very solid gameplay that can easily give you countless hours of enjoyment that constantly leaves you with the feeling of wanting to play just one more run.

I have 100%ed the game, finally after three years.   It was frustraiting and hard - the random generated items and rooms at times felt so unfair, like there was always someone against me, an invisable hand keeping me from some of the harder achievements... but, no one was against me. It is just the very nature of the game itself to be honestly brutal. Are you up for a challenge? Even when the game gives you nothing, will your skills be enough to press on and be victorius?    Challenge accepted. I was victorius. It's now your turn!   I was very impressed with this game. I played it for free (Hacked version!) for 250+ hours. However, I knew that buying the game and supporting the creator was the best way to make sure more games like this get created. The level of detail to balance... the skill needed to beat the game... All the items that had super uniqueness about them... Priceless. Happily I bought the game and the expandsion, and it was even better than the hacked version. Tons better than the hacked version!   It is really unbelievable how wonderful this game is.   500 hours of my life, enjoyed so very much. I will be buying the remake in a heartbeat. To anyone on the fence about this game, there's really only one thing to say...    Get in the Box.

The Binding of Isaac has all you expect from a rogue-like: permadeath, randomized levels and items, tons of secrets and achievements to discover, unlockables...  What did it for me is the ambiance. The story is minimal but still original, and is served well by a gorgeous soundtrack, simple yet nice looking graphics, and surprises like the arcade, the secret rooms, and so on.  A downside of the game, for me, is the utter randomness of it. Sometimes you'll get lucky and have a super build, sometimes you'll just get crappy items over crappy items. I should warn you about it's difficulty, too. Some rooms are very hard and you need extra quick reaction time not to get hurt, and this is where Flash was a bad choice, making the game laggy when too many elements are on screen.  Overall, it's still an awesome game that I recommended to lots of my friends, and some of them are even more hooked than me.

Just about everything about this game was done with polish, and then some. It's mindless, yet, if you care to explore the story itself, the game gets really deep, really dark, and really fast. Just about every item in the game has some kind of allusion, all the monsters were EXTREMELY well thought out in their design (and more importantly their naming), and the music is the typical Indie dreamboat soundtrack that Edmund McMillen whips up every now-and-again.  For the most part, even if you could care less about the story, music, or art, the game is downright FUN. It's (obviously) punishing, since it's a rogue-like, ridiculously simple to pick up but hard to master, and no two runs are the same. If you really want something that's BAD about this game, the only thing that really comes to mind is the lack of co-op, local or otherwise (solved in Rebirth), and item balance (for the most part, one of the first things you'll hear about this game is just how ridiculously broken Ipecac or Mom's Knife can be).  One of the very few games that I can say should be priced HIGHER, can only see that it's dropped in price probably because of how spoiled the community is with sales. Back when it was $10, it often went on sale for a whopping $2USD WITH DLC. I won't lie, I bought it at that price tag. Had I known how damn awesome this game would be, I'd have honestly bought it full-price.  Please do yourself a favor and get the DLC, it practically doubles the content.

This is my first review so feedback on how I did would be appreciated.  This was one of the first games I got on steam. Some friends told me that it was not worth its full price and I should just wait for the discount but I didnt listen to them. This game is completely worth its price. Its only five dollars without the DLC and eight dollars with the DLC making it extremely cheap. This game requires very little power so I could play it on my terrible laptop. When I first started playing this game I was so bad at it and I wondered how anyone could ever beat it. But if you play this game for the first few rounds you will start to want to play more and more and beat what you got last game. The first ten times you beat the game, even if its with the same character, you get something new. Then you can beat it with all the other characters. Every character has their good parts and bad parts. Character choice is also a crucial decision even in the late game making you really have to figure out who you like to pay as. Some poeple say that this game is very small and that is true but you have to remember that this actually started out as a flash game. ocne youve beat the game a lot it starts to feel a bit repetative but to give you an example of what I mean by a lot, I have played over 200 hours of this game and only in the past 2 hours or so did I start to feel it getting boring. But that means that I got about 25 hours of gameplay for every dollar I spent. This is a great game if you like roguelike games. Every run is either a bit or completely different from the others depending on what items you choose to pick up. This isnt a multiplayer game but its fun to play around friends to see peoples different strategys. I really enjoyed this game and all my friends hate me because I played to much of it. 9.5/10 Stats: Money: 10/10 (Really cheap game) Controls: 10/10 (They work and they're easy to learn) Sound: 8/10 (The soundtrack is ok, I dont normally play with volume on) Replayability 10/10 (200 hours, each run is about a half an hour need I say more?)

In The Binding of Isaac, you play as a young boy of about 4 who, on the run from his demented mother who wants to sacrifice him to God, falls into a twisted basement full of grotesque and horrifying creatures whom he must fight...by crying on them. In this game there is permadeath--no checkpoints; if you die you must start over from the beginning. In each procedurally generated floor, there are progressively greater numbers of rooms filled with progressively harder enemies. Within these rooms you get pickup items such as bombs and keys, as well as collectible items that upgrade your character with such effects as increased fire rate, homing tears, flight, and many many more. The enemies are varied and entertaining, the endless RNG ensures that no two runs are the same, and the selection of nearly 200 items will have Isaac finishing every run with a different look and different abilities. This is an absolutely brilliant game with well-balanced difficulty, (that is, hard, but not rage-inducing Dark Souls-tier hard) tight controls, amusing art, and endless replay value. Go ahead and spend the small price of five dollars. I assure you you won't be disappointed.

Binding of Isaac is as incredible as it is simple. You can run in four directions and you can shoot in four directions. However the replayability (as over 400 hours playtime on my account proof) is unimaginable. Wanting to rerun the game and always thinking that it could still get better keeps one playing the game. The graphics surely are a matter of taste. They have a nice cartoony look but still is quite gory at the same time. The music is great. For a game that you're probably going to play for countless hours you need a fitting music that doesn't make you want to cut your ears off. And the melodies in this game surely manage to avoid that unpleasant incident. They are almost kind of subtle and somehow manage to be catchy at the same time. The controls, again, are really simple but fit the game since you really only can run, shoot and use some items. So in my opinion a simple 'yes' doesn't quite fit this game. I would rather go for 'hell-a doodle yeah' or something similar in meaning.

A game you can play for almost an infinite period of time. I've clocked a hundred hours or more on this while traveling on my Laptop and playing offline and I still love playing it once in a while. I don't think I've even completed it more than a few times and I don't even care.  Now for some complaints: No native controller support. Odd for a game like this. And the dev even goes so far as to tell you to deal with it and use some third party program to map your keyboard.  Can get frustrating at times because your success in the game relies mostly on two things: Complete and utter RNG and playing the game a lot. The more you play, the more things you unlock.  I could nitpick for a while, but there's no point. I love the game.  Breakdown: Graphics: 7/10 (A point granted for how much work they put in to giving all the items you pick up visual effects) Sound: 8/10 (The music is pretty solid, but aside from grunting and moaning there isn't much variety.) Gameplay: 9/10 (Not perfect, but it comes pretty close for this genre.) Total: 8/10. A complete steal at 5 bucks, and the DLC is completely worth it. Doubles the size of the game. Literally.  Keep an eye out for the remake/sequel of this which will have a real game engine, run at higher than 30FPS and include a mind numbing level of additional content and reworks.

The Binding of Isaac is one of the best indie games I have played in quite a long time, and I plan on happily purchasing Rebirth when it is released.  This game has literally been heaven and hell for me. :3 (bit of spoilage in this review)   Every run you start, you never know how it's gonna go down. Are you gonna make it past the first room? Find a great item drop? Die by spiders (ALL THE TIME)? Make it to    Sheol    or the    Cathedral?    It's all in how you play the game, and the more you play the more you learn and the less you suck, as it is with all games. I must admit that this game can be built off of sheer luck at times, and other times it puts you down before you get past the first floor. It's a roll of the dice, you can end up with a    Dead Cat    or    Tech. II   , but that's what makes it so fun and increases the replay factor, because you want to have the mother of all runs. And who doesn't? The thrill of reaching the    Cathedral    and fighting    Isaac   , then dying and realizing its all over can be a let down, but it only makes you want to go back and do it again, but win.   Overall (from my jumbled and discombobulated piece of poop review), I simply love this game. It's got the golden touch that only comes along once in a million other games, and its almost impossible to quit. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys indie games, who doesn't already have it. It's a must play, and don't let some of the negative reviews pull you away from a masterpiece.

Magnificent, incredibly addictive Rouge-like game, randomly generated with dark and humorous themes aswel as great soundtrack and gameplay, isaac is all about luck and skill, aswel as planning ahead, you can't just throw yourself into hordes of enemies without studying their A.i., many times will item effects be confusing and there is no way of knowing what an item will provide when picked up, but part of isaac's charm is not knowing what they do before you've picked them up, after completing the game at 100% and having massed up 80+ Mom Kills (and over 200 deaths) i can very much say this game is worth much more than what it costs, even more while on sale, can't wait for Rebirth (a remake under a better engine) comes out to enjoy isaac without Flash's laggyness, 10/10 spent 90 hours playing it and will spend many more in the future

What could I say about this game? Well, first off, that it is rife with bizarre imagery. The deformed, nightmarish enemies, gore and escatological content make the atmosphere disturbing. Yet, as surreal as the game can get at times, this can be overlooked thanks to the fact that its gameplay is absorbing and the randomly generated elements make sure that each game is different from the last one. At times the Random Number God will be merciful and a playthrough will be easy. Others, it will smite you with waves of difficult enemies and a lack of helpful items when you most need them. Also, each time you beat it, it gets a little tougher. But, unlike in most Roguelikes, never is your defeat to be blamed on randomness. With skill, you will be up to any challenge it puts before you. A good purchase if you like Roguelikes and the old Zelda games.

This game is a roguelike that pays homage to the original Zelda dungeons with randomly generated floors and treasures within. The RNG makes it so at times it can be really difficult, and at others, really easy. It's a game where you can go from doing well to dead in a matter of seconds if you aren't careful.  Because of the skill requirement, completing the later floors gives you a great sense of achievement, and you'll be tense with the suspense of combat, all while accompanied by an awesome soundtrack that captures the atmoshpere of the game.  The graphics, while not as amazing as Rebirth, are still pretty good considering what this game was inspired by. Personally, I find a charm in them.  In closing, I'll say what others have said before me: I hate this game, it hates me, yet I can't stop playing.  10/10 IGN

I wrote this a couple of years ago. While it was true at the time, there is no reason to buy this game. Instead check out its sequel: The Binding Of Isaac: Rebirth. In comparison, this game is horse ♥♥♥♥.  By far the best value for money on Steam, The Binding of Isaac guides you through layers of depth and despair. The main story is that the child, Isaac, must flee through the randomly generated levels of his own basement to escape his homicidal mother. The rooms are filled with terrifying monsters and Isaac must fend them off by shedding his own tears. At the end of each floor, there is a boss room and there are many different kinds of optional rooms that will provide Isaac with powerful bonuses or fearful punishments.  The game is fiendishly difficult, with a health meter shown as a few precious hearts. Once you die, you have died for good and you’ll have to start afresh. The game has about 200 items that change the stats of the player as well as provide extra methods of survival and by the later floors Isaac should have a few helpful assets to help him achieve victory. At this point, the game will get LONGER and HARDER, so it really is a game that will keep bringing you back for another Isaac run. The DLC, Wrath of the Lamb, is an absolute must have for this game, as it adds 75% more content to the game in levels, secret room types, items, enemies and bosses. If you’re looking for a cheap game to last you a long time, this is it.
Countless hours of fun. You also get to kill monsters

This game is amazing. As I chug ever closer to the hundreth hour of playtime, I wonder. Why does THIS game in particular hold my attention so much? Well, you see, this game is a randomly generated rougelike permadeath romp through your basement as you drown your opponents in tears. You are on the hunt for your mother who tried to sacrifice you to whatever voice she heard in her twisted mind. Pure gaming bliss. Even more reason to play this game is the sheer amounts of items that will alter your journey. Ever wanted to vomit bombs? How about vomiting bombs that make a rotation around you and ultimately deal more damage to you than anyone else? How about launching missiles from the sky to rain down upon your enemies? How about shooting lasers from your mouth? If any of this sounds fun at all, (other than the whole bombs redirected at you thing) you should pick up this game. It's pretty cheap to boot!  Unfortunately, there are negatives. Like I said before, some item combos can screw you over. Also, since this game runs on flash, it will lag. A lot. There are more glitches than you can count, all of them unpatchable due to flash's limitations. But does this mean it's a bad game? No. Not at all. This is one of my top ten favorite games of all time, and I can't even describe the replayability of this game. The variety that this game will bring to the table is astonishing. If you're looking for a way to waste lots of your time, this is it. By the way, don't pick up the DLC until you know what you're doing. It will make this already difficult game into something truly nightmarish. But hey, I won't stop you.

Woo! another round of writing reviews. Lets get to it? Binding of isaac for the most part, draws from roguelike elements, namely permadeath and randomized environments. Each 'run' through binding of isaac is very quick, if you're new. This quad-directional shooter is going to ♥♥♥♥ you. I mean you have NO chance at the start, but then you start getting better and better, learning when to take an item, and when not to, how to deal with certain mobs/bosses etc. The levels in binding of isaac consist of usually 8-10 small rooms, each of which are randomized with different mobs, types and loot. For example, you have the arcade, stuffed with gambles for your hard earned pennies, you have the 'Deal with the Devil' room where you can trade off health for high risk/reward items. The art style is very much appreciated, some runs I end up with cross-dresser Isaac, some I end up with Demon Isaac, all of them look awesome. And by that I mean, each item can give you an appearance change, like demon horns, replacing an eye with a laser beam and all that good stuff. The storyline is insignificant, but cheesy and hilarious, namely a 1 minute video at the start explaining the situation that the game starts you off in, on every run, though if you are thinking of buying this for the story-line alone, don't. This is an all-gameplay fun run-to-your-death game which has massive replay value(One guy even has a playthrough series of 500+ episodes). It is also a flash game. I don't mean that in a bad way, I was shocked when I heard this was made with flash.  Protip edit- Download Binding of Isaac Spidermod. For arachnophobes; there is no spiders added in the mod, but there are already plenty in the game itself. Spidermod simply adds 1080p, fixes help strings and other good things. Fully recommend it. In this game, you die a lot, but you start to get better. As you progress, you live longer. Every time you die, the game restarts, but with different items to pick up as powerups. Depending on which powerups you find each time you play, you might just survive enough to win. Then you start winning more. And more. And it never gets old. With over a hundred randomized items and completely randomized dungeon maps each time, you can die 100 times in a row and still have fun.

BoI is a no holds bar, kick you to the curb, stomp on your face, and laugh at you as you fail kind of game. But something keeps you coming back for more. This game is not for the weak spirited, and it will try to break your spirit, but don't let it. Push on, keep going, because there is an amazing game waiting for you. You will also experience one of the best game soundtracks in the entire industry.  Every time you scratch and claw just to make it 1 floor further than before, it really gives you a sense of accomplishment. That sense of accomplishment seems to be missing from a lot of modern games, and Isaac truely feels like a difficult, engaging game.  For the price, you can't afford to miss out on this game. Check it out!

Ahhh, the binding of isaac, Zelda and Dark souls' love child, and I say this without any exageration. This is a game with a stunning amount of depth to it, as a new player, you are thrown into the game knowing literally nothing but moving and shooting in a quad-directional way. Items have descriptions that are often too obscure to understand the true effect, and can only be learned by the you experimenting with it. Enjoy the fact you know nothing about the game, and enjoy the learning experience, it is a hard game with insanely high skill cap, and for this reason, you will die hundreds of times before beating the 1st final boss. Literally. And for this very reason, when you do improve, when you do learn more about the secrets and mechanics of the game, you see the reasult, instead of dying on the first 3 rooms, you can get through the entirity of the first 6 stages with no damage taken. Without any further ado, buy the game now, regardless if its on discount, its a experience you will love, savour, and contemplate. This game is what introduced me into indie gaming, and I will forever thank the person that introduced me to this title

The Binding of Issac is a very simple game. You move, shoot, drop bombs, and use items. Standard dungeons crawler stuff. But at the same time, The Binding of Issac is one of the deepest games I've ever played. And by deep, I don't mean it'll help you discover yourself. I'd say a good fifth of the game is poop jokes. I say deep because THERE IS SO MUCH CONTENT. Hundreds of items that you'll probably never find. All kinds of bosses that you'll probably never fight. This game is incredibly addicting. It's the kind of game that you'll only launch to do something while another game updates, and an hour later you've completley forgotten about the updating game. I can not reccomend this game enough, as it'll provide hours of content. For the price it's at, for the content you get, it could be the best deal on Steam.

I admit, I was skeptical at whether or not this game was worth it. Now, I see I have been completely missing out on a face-paced, indie game of insanely joyful proportions! The controls are easy to catch onto after only a few minutes, and the game flows easily. In the beginning, expect to fail several times, but it you remain persistent then you will find yourself spending a couple hours fly by with ease. The dungeons are randomly generated each time as well as the items and enemies you face each time, so expect a different and refreshingly new playthrough everytime you start a new game :) One big feature about this game is that once or if you die, you must restart all over again from the beginning. Why this may seem malproductive to gameplay, it is rather quite ingenious and works well for this style of games. it allows you to start fresh as every gameplay, all the strategies you use, and tactics you incorporate are constantly changing as you adapt to new scenarios the game dishes out at you. I highly suggest buying this game--it is cheap and you can find it for one key on tf2op most days. I hear the dlc content adds so much more to the game as well and based on my first impressions (a.k.a. 20 hours spent playing the game over 3 days time), I am anticipating myself purchasing the dlc in the near future. Don't miss out on this amazing, albeit somewhat gruesome/dark, game.

This game is absolutely phenomenal! It starts out with a very dour story regarding a fanatical mother who hears the voice of god commanding her to sacrifice her son Isaac, who then flees into the basement to escape her wrath (only to encounter a variety of demonic creatures).   After the opening cinema, the player starts the game and is introduced to all of the necessary keyboard commands via a series of cave paintings in the first dungeon room. From there, trial and error will teach you the rest that you need to know. The rouge-like style game consists of a random series of procedurally created dungeon rooms, monsters, secrets, item drops, and treasure chests. The monsters and bosses are hideously gruesome things that display Edmund McMillen's fantastic diabolic art style. There are countless homages to past classics such as The Legend of Zelda, however TBOI's treatment feels very original and fresh this day in age.   If you are a fan of A) Team Meat, B) Zelda, C) gruesome artwork, D) fiendishly difficult game play, or E) all of the above, you owe it to yourself to give The Binding of Isaac a try. Very addictive game with a high replay rate.

The Binding of Isaac... An action RPG shooter with heavy Rogue-like elements. Do not be fooled by the cute cover image of Isaac. Being one of the most simple, yet morbid games I've ever played, I found myself strangely enjoying the disturbing feel of illustration. This isnt exactly one of those games where you can call the scenery 'beautiful'.   Upon first gameplay, you will either love the game or hate the game; however, for most people... For a flash based game being only $4.99, this is a game where you will feel your money was well spent. You play as Isaac, one of the six unlockable characters, braving your way through randomly generated levels using very simple contrls. Each floor of the basement dungeon has monsters you must clear through before you can advance to the next room. Along the way, you collect money to purchase items from a shopkeeper and find weapons and power-ups to boost your stats and chances against enemies. Each floor of a dungeon includes a boss you must fight to move on to the next level dungeon. Though the controls are very easy to play with, this does not change the fact that you will certainly be provided with challenges; expect to die... a lot.   I was lucky to catch this game on sale for 0.99, and I was very satisfied with what I got, including the DLC and soundtrack. If you have any friends seeking an exotic experience, definitely introduce this game to them.  + Randomly generated levels = endless replay value + Wide variety of items to seek and collect, adding to replay value + Morbid illustration keeps you strangely interested + Simple controls  - Since levels are randomly generated, difficulty can occasionally spike. Practice, practice, practice!

**Binding of Isaac**  Story (6/10):  BoI's story is simple; a boy is stranded in the basement of his home, chased by his abusive Mother who believes it is God's will that her son must die. In all honesty, the story is not very important to the game, and is not a focal point.  Gameplay (8/10):  BoI plays like a standard 4-directional shooter, introducing a gameplay style that is easy to learn, but difficult to master, so to speak. The game introduces numerous enemies, and staggering amounts of upgrades and items that the player must use to utilize throughout the game. Combined with an unforgivingly hard difficulty, the average player should be prepared to die. A lot. Unfortunately, the game sometimes is hindered by its forcing of the player to only shoot in the cardinal directions, since enemies come from all sides.  The game's ability to randomize the levels/powerups through each playthrough gives you motivation to continue to play, and feels satisfying throughout.  Visuals (8/10):  The game has a cartoony, Flash presentation, similar to Super Meat Boy, that is pleasing to the eye. McMullen paints a dark picture of Isaac's basement, introducing horrible creatures and disturbing imagery that is not always as cutesy as the main character. The game is obviously not trying to be a graphical powerhouse, and it works.  Sound (7/10): Solid, suspenseful music, combined with apt sound effects, give me no complaints about this aspect of the game.  Replayability (10/10):  BoI's entire purpose is to be replayed, over and over again. Games are very short, either because the player dies from the game's brutality, or finishes the playthrough (only takes an hour or so). Usually, a playthrough will unlock new items, reveal new strategies for the player to use, or provide some other incentive for the player to try again. The game tries to be addicting, and succeeds immensely. It's hard to put this game down once you pick it up.  OVERALL: BoI is successful in what it tries to do; make a rogue-like arcade shooter with RPG elements that allows for many quick plays, that incentivize the player to keep going. It's a real treat to play.  8.5/10

The Binding of Isaac is essentially a glorified flash game with a dark and edgy storyline. However, I must admit that when I'm bored and need something new to play, I find this game to satisfy (or at least expel) these feelings quite swiftly. The gameplay is simple, as are the graphics and storyline. This is the type of game I picture one would find in a modern arcade or on a flash gaming website like  Kongregate.com . I'm not necessarily recommending this horror flash game, but I can't say it isn't half-entertaining. If you have some money to blow and need a cheap game to play, The Binding of Isaac is one to consider. Otherwise, go buy a real game and stop being an idiot.

The Binding of Isaac is a bizarre retelling of the biblical tale of the same name, and it is both imaginative and horrifying. While no two playthroughs are the same, the core gameplay retains its same formula: Isaac (or any of the alternate characters you unlock) will comb the depths of a basement and its many torturous chambers in search of items. No save points. No checkpoints. No hope. The atmosphere of the game is both cute and grotesque, and this duality reminds me of Invader Zim.  Overall, the execution of the game is superb. The simplicity of the initial mechanics are inviting and the complexity that the variable stats and certain items provide give a perfect level of depth to the arcade style of play. Unfortunately, this game can be frustatingly hard and after multiple playthroughs of poor luck in item spawns, playing can seem like a chore. Fans of Dark Souls or Demon Souls who are looking for the same level of masochism in a 2D setting need look no further.   Awesome visuals that fit the art style. Responsive controls. Hundreds (literally hundreds) of items. Difficulty and complexity increase during each playthrough. Killing the final boss might be the most satisfying thing I'll do this year.  8.7/10

Let me start by saying how absolutely terrible I am at this game.  Normally I pick up a game and I'm okay at it. Not good, not bad, just okay. Eventually I start to get better at it until I consider myself 'good' at the game.  Not this one. I started out bad and have only gotten worse. All you guys are fighting Blue Baby, Isaac, Mom, even Krampus and Wrath while I can't even beat Gurdy, Pin, Larry Jr, or a few silkworms. How I was able to get a deal with the devil room and unlock Eve, I'll never know.  That said, this is a fun game. I really, really do not like the story of this game, but the soundtrack and gameplay are just phenomenal. Legend of Zelda style dungeon crawling, RNG loot drops (which have been very kind to me so far, which I think is the game taking pity on me for how terrible I am at this game. I've still barely been getting to the boss of floor one and dying there, though) and the items. So many items.  TL;DR - I've played Touhou games on Lunatic that were easier than this game, but its too fun to stop playing.

As someone who loved this game and played it non-stop, Rebirth is simply a completely better game. I've read countless reviews on how bad the new update is, but I gave up in the first few minutes because of how laggy the game is (it was made in Flash). This was great for it's time and a true classic, but once I went Rebirth, I couldn't go back.  The main problem with this game is that it was made in Flash, but Rebirth fixes that. Rebirth is only 10 dollars more expensive and better in most ways. The nice music and flash graphics (I prefer Rebirth's pixel graphics at all times besides pixelated cutscenes, but some prefer these cartoony graphics which is fine) honestly can't save this title.  Binding of Isaac, you have given me over 100 hours of fun, adrenaline and excitement, but the day your sequel came out, you died. Though we will not play you, we will still remember you and all the classic memories that will never leave us.   Summary: Just buy Rebirth.

It is baffling how much attention and praise this neanderthalic flash game has received, because after 6 hours of playing, it is now clear to me that this game is not even worth the $0.66 I paid for it.  The controls are clunky and slow to respond, the game is rife with infuriating artificial difficulty, and no matter how many times you play, you will always have to rely on luck to win. Plain and simple. Power-ups are the life blood of surviving, and those just so happen to be randomly generated and you may not get anything useful at all. As the game progresses, more and more enemies are thrown at you, so it becomes a 'shmup shooter'; a poorly crafted one.  The bottom line is that this game for masochists should end up just like the game's protagonist - in Hell.

Waste of money.  90's graphics and 80's gameplay. Not the worst game I've bought on steam but definately that half of the scale. Save your money!  UPDATE : After the overwhelming posite reviews I thought I'd put a bit of effort in, thinking maybe I missed something. No, didn't miss much. I can positively absolutely confirm that this game IS A LOW QUALITY CRAP GAME!   Update 2: After trying to play this crap again for over an hour.  Here is a grown up point of view. The graphics are horrible. A 12 year old could draw better grahics. A circle, box and 4 lines is the main character.   O [ ]--   | \ Most of the enemies are stick figures or bouncing circles of different colors.  Gameplay is near pointless and resembles that of the 80's arcade. Same thing endlessly! Randomly generated rooms with random doorways. You can't aim properly, and minor obstacles stop you in your tracks and often prevent you from obtaining the keys etc. This leads to many times being unable to continue as until you kill all the circles, squares of squiggly lines and get the key you can't move on in some rooms. The music is just annoying and after a very short time will be turned off. The sound effects are definately low tech and appear to be an after thought Many time you end up with nowhere to go so you have to start again like I've stated and the boss levels are ridiculously hard and make no sense. Shoot them 50 times they shooot you twice. Your dead! The younger players seem to like it as the endless reviews like 'Awsome game', 'Really Fun', 'Best game ever' 'Funnest game' etc showing that it does have a place for children or those children at heart. Hmmmm! If you are over 12, and want a little bit of intellectual game play then AVOID THIS! IF YOU ARE 12 or less age wise or have the mentality of herpies and are looking for a button masher, random generated 80's style, poorly executed, dungeon game that requires just simply randomly walking around shooting circles or triangle or stick figures then BUY THIS GAME or get your mummy and daddy to buy it for you! Its cheap for a reason! If you do like the 80 style monotonous type games then there is far better games than this, and far better value.

A compilation of nearly every bad game mechanic you could possibly think of complete with sloppy controls and a sense of humor more juvenile than a middle school locker room.  An excellent example of how NOT to make a dungeon crawler.

Friend bought me this game with the dc and everything. My first run saw me with brimstone and decent stats all the way to the depths where i was mercilessly ♥♥♥♥♥. 212 deaths later I still have not beaten mom once and resort to restarting each time until i get decent loot on the first floor.  This is not fun . This is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on legitimate difficuty for the sake of replay value. This is one of the worst examples of pinning a 5 dollar bill on the player and wishing him the best of luck that i've ever seen.  There should never be a time in any game ever where a player gets every room he can, stacks everything in his favor, and still does not have enough power-ups or weapons to beat a level. This is a textbook example of artificial difficulty.   That said, I still return to this game again and again. This is one of those games that is pure torture porn and only appeals to people who want to loathe their games and feel the sweetness of totally crushing them (even if it's only because the game finally threw the player a bone)  If this is not you. Do not buy this game.

The introductory movie was interesting and entertaining, but that is about all I can put in the pros column. The game play is something you'd see 15 years ago. I know, nostalgia is becoming all the rage, but it feels like a cop out that indie developers are using to put out poor production value. I'm not slamming all indie work, there is quite a bit of good stuff out there. Next, this is a rougelike. Again, I know rougelikes are becoming popular. But I just don't find it fun to loose all progress and start over from the beginning with a randomized map. It makes me feel like I wasted my time. I got a bit intrigued about the various items and collectibles, but you apparently have to use them to find out what they do, and even then I wasn't sure what happened. You can't jump on the Apple bandwagon of providing no user assistance, when your user interface is not intuitive. There may have been an interesting story here, but I'm not going to punish myself to unfold it.

The game isn't exactly bad, but I personally didn't enjoy it. The challenge is basically dodging crap whilst shooting at weird stuff, and running around a zelda and rogue inspired maze, with some obstacles and lots of flies and poop.   I feel like the difficulty is too manufactured with it basically being you die and have to start from the beginning. I mean I guess its an original sort of idea with its nightmarish theme, but at the same time, the game doesn't pull me into to actually want to keep replaying it.   But I think the game suffers from too much repetitive gameplay for little player reward. And for me there isn't anything interesting in the game or anything 'gameplay-wise' original to enjoy.
