Stop reading this review and go to the store page for Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, the definitive remastered collection of the game that continues to get content updates. If you're reading this far, you will like the game, and the remaster is easily worth the x3 price of this original version because it includes the xpac and controller support as well as updated graphics.  That being said, what would happen if you took the Legend of Zelda (the first one) and ripped out the overworld, leaving only the dungeons to crawl through? Then what if you added hundreds of tools, and randomized the layout of the dungeons, tools, and bosses? Well, a lot of people would cry about not being able to beat the RNG boss - but add a coat of creepy religious body horror, and you'd have Binding of Isaac. Brilliant!

From the creators of a game about sentient meat trying to rescue his girlfriend from a fetus so he can get layed comes The Binding of Isaac. A game about a naked little boy trying to kill his radical christian mother using tears, aborted siblings, satanic pacts, and infections.   I love this game.

I'd like to address something before praising this game.  THIS IS NOT AN EASY GAME. With randomly-generated dungeons, numerous enemies, and an overwhelming amount of items (which can both help and harm you), it's difficult to get a firm grasp on the gameplay. This game will take a lot of practice and memorization before you can successfully play through. I do not reccommend this game to casual players.   With that out of the way, Binding of Isaac is a fantastic game to both adventure fans and top-down shooter fans alike. Personally, it feels like a healthy mix between The Legend of Zelda on NES (with all the secrets and permanent items) and Smash TV on the NES/SNES (with the shooting mechanic and enemies with semi-difficult attacks to avoid). The game also feels very different every time you play. As I mentioned before, the dungeons are randomly-generated, so you will never know what you will find/face first. Maybe you'll immediately find the ability to fly. Maybe you'll be bombarded by monsters, but for a decent reward. Maybe you'll find an item that will lead to your terrible demise (like I said, memorize everything). Depending on your taste and sense of humor, the plot and atmosphere can be strange, offensive, or absolutely hilarious. The game has a ridiculous amount of blood, religious references, etc. If none of this offends you, you will find yourself enjoying the satire this game has to offer.  I'm not sure what else I can point out at the moment. The game is fairly simple, so there isn't a whole lot to address. Just run, shoot, buy, bomb.  As for the price, I think $5 is well worth the money for this game. However, the game does go on sale rather often (I purchased it for about $2.75), but if you can't find a sale right away, buy it at full price. I guarentee you will not regret paying that $2.25 more.

A game I dismissed when I first tried it, only really got into it second time around when I tried to get into it. I must say it was worth the effort of giving it a shot. Now I'm eagerly awaiting Rebirth.  Now I do consider this game as having a few flaws, but mainly due to the RNG nature of the game. The game can become VERY frustrating if you don't luck out with decent items in a run. The game can swing from a breeze in one run to a complete hell in another run - all due to RNG. You will get decent items, decent enemies and have a blast going through but at times it will be the complete opposite.  Will require skill, getting used to, baring through with RNG but can be VERY rewarding, very fun and an interesting ride. The story is grim, dark, at times WTF'ish but all around Binding of Isaac (with it's expansion Wrath of the Lamb) is worth getting into ESPECIALLY if you're a loot-loving gamer.  4 tears / 5 tears - waiting for Rebirth for the more retro feel and NO FPS swings due to Flash.

The Binding of Isaac is a weird yet fun and interesting game. You play as Isaac, a boy who is trying to escape being killed by his crazy mother. The thing that makes this game cool is that it is all random. You never get the same rooms in the same game and all the items are randomly generated. As you progress through the game you get upgrades that help you gain defense, offense, movement, or size.  There are many creative monsters and bosses in the game. They get harder as you go through the levels and it is somewhat hard to actually progress in the middle but gets a little easier. This game is good for people who like a challenge. I do recommend it though as it is fun most of the time.

Hands down, one of the greatest games I've ever played! I can't emphasize it enough! Never have I come across another rogue-like with such unique features packed into one game. With Rebirth just around the corner, I highly suggest giving this game a go before diving face first into the mysteriously designed world that Isaac is forced to battle in. Not only will it help you become familiar with the long list of items that upgrade/degrade your character (including how they interact with one another), it will also give you a better perspective on the game's insane difficulty. All in all, while the amped up games like GTA and CoD are constanly being given high ratings, I'd without a doubt give this game a 10/10. It's far more exhilarating than those games and the replayablility makes it a never-ending quest to see what else you're capable of. Lead game designer, Edmund McMillen is a f***ing master at what he does and this one definitely reflects his incredible creative ability. Cheers!

This game is brutal. It's brutal in every possible way: it's hard, harsh and may even offend some people. You play as a kid who has to travel across the dungeons where everything wants you dead, especially your own mother. It feels like a rougelike game with realtime action and you have to use various items you find across the journey to survive. This game will kill you - many many times. However these deaths are not cheap deaths (killed because you have to die) - it's all about your skills. This game is tough to master but when you do it - you will find yourself sucked into the action for hours.  One of the best modern rougelike games. The game has a recognisable style of Edmund McMillen (of Super Meat Boy fame) featuring his twisted visions and dark setting. If you fing this game disgusting or offensive - give yourself a favor and give this game a chance. The gameplay is stellar and deserves everyone's recognition.

The Binding of Isaac is an awesome game. How can I start?  First of all, it is a game that is easy for starters, but hard to expert, because when you do the first chapter, it is in a normal difficult, but when you're almost reaching the end? It needs a lot of agility on your fingers, pal. Plus, one of the achievements, if you see, is 'Everything is Terrible' that makes the game harder, and it really becomes harder, and very fun if you know how to play. Obviously, everyone have their rages on the game, I admit, that's normal.  Now, about the items, well, in this version, have some awesome items that doesn't stacks with others... and that can be annoying sometimes. But how they look, their effects, or how isaac look with them, can make you laugh a lot, or you can make the famous 'WtF?' face.  The Graphics, well, let's skip this, because they are good, but I prefer the Rebirth style, sorry folks, but not today.  The story... I will let you find by yourself, sometimes can be a little... confusing, but not that hard to understand... most of the parts...  For the End, the characters. It is really interessing how each character have their own starting gimmicks (different stats, starting items, etc) and it is really good if you want a challenge... or if you want to use another character to unlock another items...  Anyway, it is a game where fun never ends, it worth its price (including if you count some game bugs, unfortunately, but they are rare to happen) and I really apreciate it, no matter what.

There are three items you can stack which are pennies, bombs, and keys which help you do things. Also can be played in one sitting easily, butt change each time for replayability.

The Binding Of Isaac is a game I have been playing a lot recently. Picture running through the dungeons of Legend of Zelda, with one constant item and one item you can switch around and you have the basic setup of the game. You start off by selecting a character which controls your starting stats and items. Then you enter the first level of the dungeon to start your quest. Along the way you'll collect money, bombs, and keys which you can use to get into treasure rooms, shops, arcades, secret rooms and more. At the end of every level is a boss. What gives the game its great replay-value is that the levels are randomly generated, as are the items you'll encounter, and the bosses are randomly picked from a group of monsters who can show up in the given area. With over 100 items you'll end up playing through the game very differently depending on what items you can get your hands on.  The controls are very simple: shift to drop a bomb, space to use an item (if you find one that needs activation) and Q to eat a pill/use a tarot card. Killing all the monsters in a room will give you Tarot cards, bombs, keys, pills, hearts, money, and if you are really lucky a chest. The tarot cards have mostly good effects. Pills can add or take away from any of your stats, so be careful with them unless you have the lucky foot or the Ph.D. Silver chests can contain any of the above pickups including another chest. Gold chests need a key to open, but can give you an item or a heart container in addition to what a silver chest can hold.   On every floor there should be a treasure room, represented by a crown on the map. Make sure you save a key to get in because the items are free, and a lot of good items can only be found here. There is also a shop on every floor, but I'd only enter if you have plenty of keys and at least 15 cents. The good items cost 15 cents unless they are on sale. Be prepared going into the shop, because the mini-boss Greed can be waiting inside. If he shows up, you'll be locked into a fight with him, and will not be able to buy items when you are done.  One of the dangers you can run into are the seven deadly sins. Acting as mini-bosses they'll randomly show up in an unexplored room to ambush you. Luckily they aren't that difficult to defeat once you know their moves. The hardest of them is probably greed, who shoots 3 shots in a spread somewhat randomly and tends to hang out in the shop when you need to buy something the most.  You'll also find secret rooms, challenge rooms, arcades and other interesting rooms and creatures on your journey. Although the game is simple on the surface, there is a lot going on underneath. Take money for example. On the surface you can spend it at the store or gamble in a slot machine. You'll also find a beggar who you can give it to. Low on money? Drop a bomb on the slot machine (or the beggar) to get some money back (hopefully). Item Synergies are another fun thing to explore as you try and find a working strategy to get past the final bosses. There are a few items that can instantly kill some troublesome bosses. The trick is figuring out which ones work where and finding them.  Expect to die many times while you figure out how to get past the monsters, traps, and bosses. And expect to have a great time doing it. As you progress further the enemies can get pretty nasty. But hey, there is a great item that unlocks from dying 100 times, so get to it.  Once you figure out the game, completing the entire game will only take you an hour or so(Before you figure out the game, your games will be much shorter!), but it is still very enjoyable to load up again and again, finding new items every time. I think a lot of the reason I love it is because I know one game won't be a huge time commitment.  Pros:  List of items that might appear.  The game works on Steam.  Lots of built-in and steam enabled achievements. The achievements will unlock new items, bosses, and areas, so they are actually worth getting beyond bragging rights.  Multiple characters and a ton of items you can find give a lot of replay value. There are also a lot of different bosses to fight.(I'm over 60 hours myself and haven't unlocked the last bonus area yet.)  Small time commitment - Completing the entire game will only take an hour or so.  Entertaining references to many other video games such as Super Meat Boy, Legend of Zelda, and more.  Great Soundtrack! I spent the extra dollar to have the soundtrack. (You have to go to the steam game folder to find it.)  The game is very reasonably priced at $4.99 when it is not on sale.  Cons:  There are a few bugs with the DLC which cause the game to slow down a bit between levels. Nothing critical or that caused me to lose my game.  As you might be able to tell from the picture above, the game has disturbing imagery. It didn't particularly bother me, but I could see it bothering people.   The game is done in Flash and so it doesn't quite work with the steam overlay, meaning you can't upload screenshots directly into steam.  Final Thoughts:  This game is great, and well worth buying at full price. You can usually get it much cheaper during a steam sale and the winter sale is currently going. The Best deal for this game right now is at the humble bundle site. Pay whatever you want for BoI and the DLC and other games!  There is a DLC available for this game and it is also great and inexpensive, however, it does make the game harder. I'd wait until you have beaten the game a few times before adding the DLC.

It's a Flash game where you play as a naked crying boy and you have to kill your mother.  It's immensely difficult, mainly owing to the fact that there's a certain limitation with Flash where you can't save your progress (Rebirth will fix that, by the way). That means that, in order to beat the game, you have to go through the entire game without dying once. It's a challenge, especially since getting most of the really good stuff is based around actually just being lucky enough to find it.  It's really fun, though. It's a great feeling to get all the way to the final main level, Depths II, even if you die there. It's a great experience, it's got a pretty good soundtrack, and it's just overall fun to play.

Gah, this game is frustrating, yet it keeps calling to me every time I look down my list of games to play. In fairness, I rarely put more than half an hour into it per sitting, but it's a great 'pick-up and play title.' I suppose my main criticism is that without having the wiki open, there's no way to see what the various 'pick-ups' do; A pretty big issue for a game of this type, considering the sheer amount of different pick-ups.  On the whole, it's fun, funny and frighteningly disturbing when you're collecting feminine products and fetuses to use as weapons. I'd recommend it as one to sit in your library to fill a spare half-hour if you can pick it up on the cheap, but it's not going to be one of your most played games by a long shot. Definitely has replayability and as the levels are randomly generated, you won't feel like you're repeating yourself. I still haven't 'won the game' so I'm keeping it installed and will give it more attempts in the near future.

The Binding of Issac  Story You are Issac a child who was born and raised by his mother but has now gone crazy, she hears the voice of God who tells her that her son is with sin and must be sacrificed for God to cleanse him of his sins, so his mother grabs the kitchen knife and bursts through Issac's door and Issac notices a trap door underneath his carpet and escapes into the basement below where he will face horrifying creatures before inevitably facing Mom herself.  Gameplay The gameplay is very simple WASD to move and the arrow keys to shoot Issac's tears, the game is very focused on collecting items that will help you in your fight with the creatures in the basement. The Binding of Issac is a randomly generated dungeon like rogue style RPG that will have you upgrade Issac and have you make deals with the Devil and the Angel. And is really really hard... ha ha... sorry uh lost my maturity then.  Graphics The graphics are great for this type of game but because of it being a flash game The Binding of Issac is very pixilated game with nice enough looking enemies and environments.  Music However the music is phenomenal it sticks with you throughout your day and is one of the reasons why we love The Binding of Issac because the soundtrack makes you want to come back for more.   The Binding of Issac is a game that you must give time into but is extremely addicting ONE DAY I WILL COMPLETE ONE OF THESE RUNS and the music is brilliant hooks you every time plus the price is always really low on sale you may as well get it.  The Binding of Issac   8/10  Would spend £0.49 again.

This game is a perfect example of how minimal resources can accomplish a lot. Games don't have to be gigabytes to be fun, and The Binding of Isaac takes that premise and runs with it.  With elements of puzzle, action, and adventure, on top of a dark, but interesting storyline, this game is perfect to kill some time. Each playthrough is fairly unique, as the levels are randomly generated.  While there's no controller support here, the sequel has built-in controller support.  Overall, a must-have for any Steam library, and perfect for systems that don't have a lot of processing, such as low- to mid-end laptops.

The Roguelike genre deserves more recognition. NetHack and Infra Arcana have laid dead for what seems like millenia, remnants of a forgotten era of games. And from their dusty, instruction-heavy husks bursts forth this demonic baby.  This game breaks the mold of the industry, and dares to respect your intelligence. It doesn't coddle you...it leaves you, like a frightened child, to fend for yourself. You're forced to explore and experiment. You don't know what anything does or is until you pick it up and use it. Every playthrough is a learning experience, contributing to your next playthrough, both by expanding the player's knowledge, and unlocking new content. You will have a fresh experience every time. Sometimes you'll be lucky, sometimes you'll get your ♥♥♥ kicked, but that's half the fun. I highly recommend buying the expansion after your first few playthroughs, so you can get the basic rhythm before making things more complex, but buying it alongside isn't a horrible idea.

The Binding Of Isaac is a rogue-like like you've never played before. The story of this game is that Isaac's mother is attempting to kill her son after God tells her to. Isaac flees and find a trap door hidden under his rug. He proceeds to jump down into the unknown depths below (his basement).  In this game, you will counter a multitude of items, a lot of crazy looking enemies, a buttload of bosses and poop! You heard me. Poop. You can get coin drops from destroying poop. ANYWAYS, to get down to it, Isaac's weapon of choice is his tears. He cries on his enemies. I know. Just when you thought this game couldn't get any weirder. Isaac has multiple stats which items will often change in a positive manner: fire rate, shot speed, damage, speed, range and health. You will probably notice, when starting the game, that there are multiple characters to play as all with they're own stats.  I'd say it's a buy.  Oh and get the DLC! It adds about 100 items or so to the game and lots of monsters and bosses! :)

So much fun. Randomly generated levels, cool items and powerups, easy controls...I'll probably never unlock Platinum God (I'm not nearly that good at games in general), but if you are a gamer looking for a challenge, and don't feel like spending $15 USD on the newer version, pick this one up.

If the Devil made Legend of Zelda  Bind of Isac is a top down action rpg that pays its roots to the original legend of zelda but now its thrown in rouge like elements and traded whimsical fantasy for dark and desturbing gothic horror.   you explore various radomly generated floors looking for preasious upgrades and trying to uncover the boss of each level to defeat and advance.  This game is hard as hell. the enemies start brutal and the upgrades and items you discover are completly random which means you might not be able to get upgrades because you have no keys or even if you get an upgrade it might not be particualy useful and if you die you lose all progress. the only thing that stays is once you've discovred somthing new theres a higher chance of encountering it again in another play through.   That being said the game is fun and addictive. the enemies have learnable patterns so with enough practice you'll be able to power through them reguardless what upgrades you get. Like any good rouge like you'll want to give it another try as soon as you die. And everytime you beat the game new things unlock (including deeper levels to the dungeon)  There is a story but its kept to a minimum once again nodding to its nes inspired roots.   All and all its a fun retro styled game with good use of modern game design. Hard but fun...if kinda freaky

I've always been a fan of double stick games dating way back to Robotron and as recent as Super Stardust. From the preview video of The Binding of Isaac, I had hoped it would be Robotron meets Legend of Zelda. Granted, the game is in many respects but has a lack of joypad support. It also is displayed in a window and cannot make it full screen. I wish they would port this indie game for the PS Vita. The game is good enough for me to fumble with the keyboard controls to play. This is a long game and there is NO SAVE! It's one long playthrough! Each level and monster generation is random which keeps the gameplay fresh. Takes a little practice and luck to get powered up enough to survive. A real bargain when on sale.  UPDATE: I now use JoyToKey.exe to play the original BoI and it works very well! They have since released the Remix verision which is also a great game and is also on the PS Vita! Negative reviews say the new game is too pixelated (on purpose) and has a different soundtrack (true, but also good). Both game are a joy to play over and over. So many unlockables! Love the challenge!

Extremely good top-down rogue-like game about an abused little kid. The first 50 hours will be full of frustration (and hopefully motivation) because starts out beeing very hard. When you finally beat that final boss (you should beat the very final boss after around 60 hours I guess) it is EXTREMELY satisfying (I even jumped out of my chair out of joy after so many failed attempts).  I have played it well over 800 hours (mostly outside of steam for the most part for speedrunning reasons), just because there is so much to master and learn about this game, it is insane.  Even after you learnt all of it, broke the game into peaces and completed it 1000 times in 1000 different ways, you can still try to speedrun it. There was an active speedrun community (they all play rebirth now) that was highly competetive, even though the game has a lot of rng in it (What items you get etc.)  You should buy this game or rebirth (which is a remake that also added a LOT of stuff), you won't regret it.

So much replay value here, even if you don't get the DLC. If you pick up this game, grab the DLC, you won't be sorry. I only have about 25 hours in this game, but considering I only spent about 6 bucks total on it, I'd say it was more than worth it, and I will be playing it MUCH more.

One of my favorite games of all time. Though I m starting to hate it a little bit:D  What so great about this game? The variety of course! Every, EVERY time you start you're a gonna have a different experience: different map, different sets of enemies, bosses, bonuses and, most importantly, items. Because there is a LOT of them even to start with, and you are constantly unlocking new ones. Passive items, active items, trinkets, pills, cards. And after some them different characters to play with too!  The most of the fun (at least for me) in the begining is discovering what that those items, for example Wire Coat Hanger, that is now sticking out of your characters head, actually did. Later into the game you'll have a lot of fun with combinations of items that sometimes lead to very interesting effect.  In addition to such a interesting game desing this game has a really dark and wicked atmosphere, that makes it even more special:)  But, be vary of the fact that this is NOT an easy game, oh no! It goes from hard to brutal to #@$%! levels of difficulty, so be prepared for the pain and be prepared to worship the gods of luck if you decide to actually complete it 100%!  Not as good as Rebirth, but still great! It's also worth noting that the game might have perfomance issues, due to it being made in flash.

A dungeon crawler game that was heavily influenced by the original Legend of Zelda on the NES. Being made by Team Meat means that this game can be brutal at times. Some of the bosses you can encounter will test your skills in dodging their attacks and memorizing their patterns. Each playthrough will be different: encountering new bosses, new enemies, new powers, new rooms, new items, and a new ending everytime you beat it up to 10-15 times, and on every run you do, you unlock even more content such as new items bosses and floors of the dungeon. The game is filled to the brim with content and refrences, and it's made even better with the Wrath of the Lamb DLC. For a game that is $5 or $7.50 with WotL this is a fonominal pick up and should at least be given a shot to play.

One of the main flaws is that unlocking all the items requires beating it a bunch of times, and while it does get slightly harder if you play after winning once or twice (by upgrading the enemies/bosses and putting harder enemies earlier) the difficulty decides to wait until your fifth win to jump up by a lot; by the third time you win it'll start seeming to have lost some of its teeth and it's not obvious in advance that it will get them back if you beat it a few more times. Be ready for that. Also, several achievements/unlocks rely a bit too much on luck and/or 'grinding' by collecting certain items in several runs.

The Binding of Isaac is what is commonly known as a roguelike game. Roguelikes are characterized by randomly generated dungeons and gear, above average difficulty, and permadeath. You died? Gotta start over in a new dungeon! The controls are simple and the gameplay is addictive. There is a lot of little humor and even more dark jokes. The game has a heavy religious overtone, referencing the Bible and other religious stories pretty regularly. The bosses early on are jokes, but in later stages, they can get pretty brutal.  Pros: - REPLAY VALUE. There are hundreds of items to unlock, and several different playable characters with unique starting items and stats -Addictive -Difficult, but rewarding -Aesthetically pleasing. Game art is in the same style as Meat Boy -Smooth gameplay  Cons: -RNG based gameplay is not for everyone, losing is common -Can be time consuming if you get bad rolls -HTML based platform, susceptible to performance issues.

This game is a wretched, vile, immoral, sacreligious, deranged piece of filth that has no place in a decent world. I love it. Wildly creative and filled with black humor, bloody combat, and mistreatment of children.  The game itself is a digital arena shooter, in the style of Smash TV, Robotron, or modern twin stick shooters: run around, collect powerups, face off against bosses, and then do it all again in a genius progression mechanic where actions in one game can unlock new items, bosses, and even levels in further playthroughs. It has surprisingly strong Valve storytelling, only expositing when you win the game, and mostly dropping hints through gameplay.

A Zelda-style room-clearing shmup bullet hell game that offers absolutely everything that it could offer. Despite randomized results and endgame stats that vary between frustrating, doable or incredibly satisfying gameplay I have continued to play BoI and found thousands of combinations of different builds and playstyles. For a long while the game can be fantastic and challenging, but it later grows stale or frustrating when you constantly obtain underpowered or nonconventional builds that detract from replay value over the course of hours.  If you're just starting, you can play this for hours on end and power through enemies with glee.  If the game runs out of juice, it's one of the best possible games you can play if you're on the go and need to kill an hour.

What a fantastic game!  This is the original Legend-of-Zelda-dungeon as a roguelike game. Should you dig too deep, the game can come off as overly dark. The seemingly-endless combinations of powerups and your latent forsight to avoid unwanted rooms makes this a very, very replayable game. Take my first comparison and add Spelunky to it. That about sums The Binding of Isaac.  Cons: sometimes provokes rage-quitting  Pros: Original-Legend-of-Zelda-dungeon has a baby with Spelunky and that baby become a roguelike badass.

A game that I think there are none other like it. A truly horrific experience based on luck, dodging, and lots of death. A game that has an undecipherable plot, a strange ammount of items that mostly help in some way, a ton of monsters with more in the DLC Wrath of the lamb, and a slght tinge of religion in the background.   You are Isaac. A young boy who lived with his mother. They were living a happy life until one day god told her to MURDER HIM. He dives into a so called 'basement' under a rug where he must fight for his life. Delving deeper and deeper until he can find an answer to his 'problem'  That's pretty much the base plot and all they give you. I left out a few things otherwise it would be a bit longer. My point is you should DEFINITELY buy the game. It may be slightly desturbing at first, but you get used to it. For 3.99 Binding Of Isaac is worth it. I VOTE YES TO THIS GAME!

The Binding of Isaac is, briefly, the original Legend of Zelda game on LSD. There are hundreds of items to find and use, and a host of enemies to defeat in randomly-generated dungeon floors. It's also very difficult, partially due to the lack of game-saving functionality. Some of the items are a little buggy as well, but it's quite a low percentage of them. Don't worry, though -- the game does have a wiki that tells you what's bugged, as well as what every item in the game does (the game is not very good at telling you what things do). All in all, I recommend it, but not for the easily disturbed or easily offended.
Basically, if you haven't already purchased this game, you should.

I'm basically in love with this game. An addictive roguelike with a typically dark twist from Edmund McMillen, this game offers simplistic controls mixed with a buttload of items and possibilities. Demented.  This game is demented. Taking its cues from the old testament bible story of the same name, The Binding of Isaac is the tale of a very little boy and his struggle for survival against a mother set on sacrificing him to a god who has demanded the act. With gameplay reminicent of The Legend of Zelda (NES), and aspects such as level randomization and perma-death, this game simultaneously scratches the action RPG and Rogue-like itches. If you have an interest in either, play this game.

Let's get one thing straight...this is not a rogue-like. I could go into the countless reasons why, but I'd rather start the review.  This game is stellar. From the fluid gameplay to the appropriate look, it's really a piece of art.Very fun and challenging. Permadeath adds to the frustration you'll already feel from the challenging difficulty level. Honestly, this game can get very stressful and send you up a wall.  Get it.

The Binding of Isaac is worth a buy if you want something different. And I mean that in a very good way. This game is a hardcore dungeon crawler with randomized floor layouts and rooms to explore. Literally every time you play this game you will find new rooms to explore. This is also coupled with the fact that the items you receive, while there is a certain number that can show up, are randomized as well. The bosses are randamized, there are certain variants of each boss, the story thickens each time you beat the game, the game will constantly suprising you, and there are different characters to unlock as well. So yeah, there is a lot of content to explore here. Now in terms of gameplay it has sort of that first The Legend of Zelda game feel. You know, top down, one item slot, upgrades, all that jazz. But this game has some rouge like elements so tht when you die, you lose all your items and upgrades. Also your attacks are completely ranged. (You also have bombs.) I wont go into the story because that would spoil some things, but overall I personally play this game evry day and love it. My rating is 10/10. I love this game. (Oh yeah, and Edmund Mcmillen made it so it's a definite buy in my book.)

Amazing, considering I have almost 200 hours in this game. Everyone that already gave it a positive review mentioned everything. The thing I would add is it has an excellent musical score. The soundtrack is worth getting as well.  On an additional positive note, owners get a substational discount on Rebirth, which is going to be even more amazing. Developer - please hurry!!

Even though I recommend this game. I must warn all players out there: buy it at your own risk.  I played the demo for this game on Newgrounds and I thought it was terrible. The controls, despite simple, were strange to me and I was sure I wouldn't get used to them in a million years. I was hilariously terrible at playing this and I have honestly never been as terrified of flies as I have during my first few runs (Imagine my joy playing Wrath of The Lamb for the first time and discovering spiders. >.>). I'd pick up the demo, play one run, maybe two, then call it stupid and terrible and rage quit... I'd do this at least once, sometimes up to three times, a day. This went on for a couple of weeks before I was finally forced to admit that I was completely in love with this game. A Steam sale was all the excuse I needed and I bought it.  My first achievement ever was dying a hundred times and my first Mom battle lasted about 5 seconds. I hated this. I hated this so much, but every time I died I told myself 'Damn it, that was so close! Just one more.... I WILL BEAT YOU GAME!'  Beating Mom for the very first time was euphoric, but it was a short lived victory as the game rewarded me with a slap in the face and a note that said 'Well done, sucker... Now do it again... and do it better! I'm not done with you!'  The Binding of Isaac is a completionist's hell. It will make you work for every victory and then raise the bar more and more until it takes away just enough of your sanity that you continue to play it against your own better judgement. It will make you hate it and yourself for ever playing it until the very last boss. Then you'll have to pick another character and do it all over again. Along the way it will also show you secrets, make you question the meaning behind everything, tease you with glimpses of what Isaac's reality might actually be and give you hopes of putting together a story that is not actually relevant to its purpose. You will descent into absolute raging madness and love every minute of it.  I've played this for over 600 hours... 600 hours I will never get back... but I will achieve Platinum God before Rebirth comes out or so help me... Can't quit now... I'm so close... I WILL BEAT YOU GAME!

I can't quite place my finger on what makes me keep coming back to this game. Masochism maybe? This unanticipated successful indie game has kept me amused for literally hundreds of hours. Any description I give won't do it justice but never-the-less I will try; BoI is easy to learn and hard to master, it's a roguelike (meaning always random, levels, items, monsters and bosses ect) the top-down view reminds me alot of the SNES and GB releases of Zelda. However the dark and twisted nature of BoI is a far cry from Link's innocent adventures. No run is ever the same, the achievements are hard to get and feel great to earn. Don't let the idea of perma-death put you off - in my opinion it's the 'every heart is sacred' (although not as sacred as the sacred heart!) that keeps the intensity and challenge going strong each and every run!  100% recommend this game it's one of my all time favourites - play it now and prepare to get excited about the remake due this year. Edmund has made mention of a discount for owner's of this version of Isaac so no need to wait!

Cons: -Sometimes you get the feeling that the game's only wish is to screw with you -It's a flash game - many people have lag issues even with a good computer (i would recommend updating flash, and video card driver to the latest avaleilable, it helped me) -Some bugs can totally ♥♥♥♥ over your best runs. A really fun roguelike Zelda-esque shooter with a large amount of content (read 30+ hours of gameplay) at a very low price. The game is especially interesting in how more content gradually unlocks for the game as you die over and over again, so it contains a sense of accomplishment even when you lose. Some people may be put off by the dark and disturbing imagery, or the game's extreme difficulty; if neither of these bother you, then I highly recommend it.

I would say to purchase the base game and ignore the WotL DLC. The base game had provided me with hours upon hours of fun and enjoyment, running through and determining how to best 'build' Isaac with what was available. However, when I purchased the DLC, I found it to be frustrating and, well, not fun. It didn't feel the same as the base game. I'm sure there are others who disagree with me, but I wish I could undo the DLC. Since it modifies the EXE for the game itself when you purchase it, there is no way to undo it.  I know that the creator of the game sees the DLC as a more 'complete' form of his image of the game, but I liked it much better without.  The Binding of Isaac is recommended, and The Wrath of the Lamb is not. Have fun crying at your enemies until they pop!

The Binding of Isaac is gross, repulsive, immature, irreverent, and really addictive. This game is the best roguelike I have ever played. You are Isaac, a neglected child living with his insane mother. When she believes God has told her to kill Isaac, Isaac escapes through the cellar.  Basically, it's Zelda crossed with a really simple twin stick shooter in which you can only shoot in four directions with your own tears. You get items that affect your character's visual appearance and basic actions - you could get an item that turns your tears into a screen-clearing laser or you could get an item that turns your character into a demonic flying creature who can shoot through walls.  This is one of the best games you can get on steam.

The Binding of Isaac is a very simple but complex shoot em up style game in the vein of Smash TV. There is some incredible depth to find with the randomly generated dungeons. The action is solid and there is some hands-free, light RPG aspects based on the loot you find. It's easy to pick up and play, but the morbid theme and perma-death may turn some away.

This game is an experience. It's certainly a wonderful experience. I've described this game as a 'Legend of Zelda Random Dungeon Generator,' and it stays true to this description. The fact that there are (I think) 200+ items with the DLC makes each time you play the game a unique experience that is nearly impossible to recreate. The only problem with it is the religious outlook on the game. It plays into the Christian ideals of the world; most of the items in the game are biblical refrences, a lot of the characters share the same names as biblical figures, and so on. But, if you can get past that and play the game for what it is, then it is a fantastic game that I certainly recomend.

I found this game to be pretty difficult, but also rewarding.   Using a keyboard, I was frankly awful at the game. Played a handful of times and didn't make it very far - very difficult for me to use a set of keys for movement and another set for shooting direction.  Switched to a game controller (Xbox 360) and did much better. Using joytokey and a config setup I found online things work pretty well. Left controller moves Isaac and right controller shoots, pretty standard stuff. Game is still tough, but I was able to make incremental progress and get better as I played. At this point I've unlocked 4 extra characters, killed Mom's first form twice and made it to the womb one time (where I died.)   There is an amazing amount of variety in this game. I've probably played 100+ games and I still see new items quite often.  Very fun game, but be sure to use a controller if the keyboard is too frustrating for you!

Even if by some stroke of luck you manage to get at it, it turns out to be a one-armed bandit - that you can't even play, because you have no money.  All of which makes victory just that much sweeter. t's disgusting, but in such a strange, over-the-top fashion that you can't help but laugh. Hands down one of my facorite games.

It's pretty difficult to pinpoint exactly why the Binding of Isaac is a stellar game. Randomly generated 'dungeons' in the style of Zelda are populated by the horrors and nightmares of an abused child (who you star as) escaping from his evangelical mother. With literally hundreds of possible upgrades (and a handful of downgrades) You roll the dice to try and make it to the end. It's extremely addicting and the complexity hidden behind it's gross humour and flash animation is staggering.   If you like Zelda, roguelikes, and have a strong stomach, this game is worth way more than it's small pricetag.

This game is absolutely marvelous, I love the visuals, I love the gameplay and it's endlessly replayable.  This is a game by Edmund Mcmillen and Tommy Refenes who have previously released the criticly acclaimed 'Super Meat Boy'. Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game in which you play as Isaac, a young boy who lives with his Christian Fanatic mother. One day Isaac's mother hears a voice telling her to prove her faith by offering her son. Isaac narrowly escapes his mothers' murderous spree through a trapdoor in his room into the basement.  This is where the adventure begins. As you venture in the basement and beyond you'll find treasures which can give Isaac an upgrade, an Item or many other things usable to escape the dangers of the basement.  This is a hard game, you'll die a lot but the playthroughs are so versatile you won't even mind. If you already have Super Meat Boy and enjoy the visuals you'll definitly enjoy the art style in this game too.

I've sunk more hours into this game than any other non-MMO title on my Steam collection. A Zelda-like 2D adventure game, with randomized levels. The set of items affords a ton of different synergies, and half the fun is seeing just how bad of a build you can get and still beat the game. There's a ton of hidden levels and difficulties to get as well. STRONGLY recommended.  One caveat: It is a fairly difficult game. The DLC, 'Wrath of the Lamb,' makes it even harder. If you consider yourself a casual gamer, you might want to pick up the normal game alone, and then pick up the DLC if you decide that you like it.

This game seems like it was specifically designed for athiests who support abortions. It's also very liquidy. That's honestly one of the best ways to describe it. But, plot wise, you're this fetus-looking dude who needs to escape from his homicidal christian mother who intends to sacrifice you to God (which seems backwards). You retreat to your basement (which is a dungeon from The Lengend of Zelda) and are met with several horribly failed stem cell experiments that want to kill you as well. You spend the remainder of the game killing monsters by crying on them and powering up Isaac by doing things like sticking a coat hanger through his head to make him cry faster. Overall, I think it's a really unique and enjoyable game to play. It can get frustrating as first, though, since you need to start the entire game over when you die (which will happen a lot). But, eventually, you'll get lucky enough to make it through the whole thing and you'll feel really proud of yourself when you do.

Perhaps the most grotesque game I've ever played, Binding of Isaac is a sadistically brutal dungeon crawler.  It has nearly unlimited replay value due to the hundreds of different power-ups one can find and the randomly generated map layouts.  Don't let the bizarre art style put you off playing this game: granted, it's a bloody mess and it's really gross at times, but the game is insanely fun and addictive.  If you enjoy a vicious challenge, if you liked the old Zeldas, if you thought VVVVVV was too easy, if you couldn't get enough of Super Meat Boy, then this game is for you.

There are many things that make this game great such as the soundtrack and the art but what really makes it great is the randomness of it. The 'troll engine' makes sure that every playthrough is completely different from the last and the replay value is immense. The 100+ different items, 7 playable characters, and all the crazy bosses make this game worth the price. NOTE: the dlc is fantastic!

In the Book of Genesis, Abraham is called upon by God to sacrifice his only son, Isaac, to prove his faith. After climbing a mountain, Abraham turns on Isaac, binds with rope, and places him on an alter. Before he can bring the knife down, God stops Abraham, telling him that he has indeed proven himself.  So what happens when 'God' calls on this Isaac's mother to do the same and doesn't call off the ritual? You get this wildly inventive top-down shooter of sorts.  You play as Isaac (there are other characters, but good luck unlocking them), a small boy that escapes his doom at the hands of his zealous mother by fleeing into his basement...only to encounter horrors beyond belief.   As you fight your way through multiple rooms (that change in every playthrough) you'll find various power-ups, pills with random effects, and tarrot cards to help you along your way...and you'll need all the help you can get because it's back to square one upon your clumsy, easily prevented death.

The style and humor in this one are truly rare. You are little Isaac fleeing from your mother who wants to kill you upon God's command... If you know your Bible you'll love this. This is a fun game that can suck hours out of your life. This game operates a lot on luck. Dungeon genreation is random and so are item spawns. Getting good items early on can make the game a whole lot easier. You could also just pick up a piece of poo (literally) which can make your life much harder.   As far as I know you can't finish this game in a single play through. You must play the game multiple times to unlock different thngs that are necessary to acheive different endings.   Thet being said late game areas can be really annoying. While early on you can avoid getting hit through skillful dodging, late game rooms and bosses can just spam out projectiles that can make dodgine almost impossible. It gets to the point where you know if you will get through the end game based on how much max health you have accumulated before that point. (That's my view but I also such at dodging shots).   All in all The Binding of Isaac is a solid game for the money. I recommend it for anyone that likes arcade style games with random dungeons.

This is not an easy game. The premise is very simple; shoot enemies with tears, collect upgrades, make your way deeper into your own insanity.  While there is a degree of strategy involved, so much of this game is dependent on the randomly generated pickups you find throughout the levels. Nothing is more frustrating than reaching a treasure room without a key, or finding a good item that replaces another one you already own rather than a stat boosting pickup.  The game is incredibly addictive, and with a much deeper and more confusing storyline than is apparent on the surface. It is definitely reminiscent of the classic top-down Zelda games and has a charmingly macabre art style.

This game is a lot of fun... Really! But there's a well-documented bug where the Flash script will freeze the game. I lost a lot of progress through this bug, and I feel slightly cheated. Sure, Edmund McMillen is a struggling indie-developer and deserves every cent he earns, but I don't like the idea of having to buy The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth and having this version lying around in my library as a ghost-title. In addition, I like this version's art-style better than Rebirth's; Rebirth's pixellation reeks of a half-♥♥♥♥♥ translation, which isn't helped by the super-fancy lighting effects of that title. I wish that Team Meat would fix the memory leaks of the flash script, but I am unfortunately certain that they won't.

This game is a rogue-like/zelda-like/2D-shooter with the following features;  - Hilariously poor Flash coding that slows down as soon as there are more than about 10 bullets on-screen at once, no matter how fast your PC is. That water-cooled 5GHz Core i7 triple-SLI gaming rig that you can run all the latest games on at 4K resolution and max settings? Hah!!! Watch as this developer brings it to it's knees with the kind of simple 2D graphics that used to run faster on a 486 back in the day. That's progress for you.  - Possibly the worse collision detection I've ever seen in this type of game. Instant death games are so much more fun when you die because your bullets went straight through an enemy, or you got hit by something that clearly didn't.  - Being told to use Joy2Key if you want controller support. Because input devices are hard, right? (PS. On Mac OSX I recommend Joystick Mapper from the app store, but it's not free. I much prefer playing with a Xbox 360 controller).  - Steam achievements don't work on OSX.  And yet... despite all that the brilliant game design still manages to shine through the shoddy implementation. It's well balanced and incredibly addictive once you get past the initial steep learning curve (and it really is steep - to succeed consistently you'll need to know how to maximise the use of limited resouces like bombs, keys, hearts, and other pickups for the best return, not to mention learning what the 100-odd different power-ups do. Or you could just read the Wiki...).  So, highly recommended if you like this type of game and have the patience to get past the above issues.  To the developer I recommend a book on the C++ programming language. Or in fact any programming language that isn't fkn Flash.

From the maker's of 'Testing-Your-Monitor's-Warranty-Service' (also called Super Meatboy), The Binding of Isaac is a short but sweet game that makes old and new gamers alike realize how much you can suck at a game with simple concepts. Legend of Zelda fans will be suffering from nostalgic migraines and keyboards will be broken. Your death count will compete with wars and the number of times you actually win will be embarrassingly low, but each one of them will be ever so sweet feeling of accomplishment that really begs for more. Just like Isaac, you will cry, kill things, and most likely drive a clothes hanger straight through your skull all in your adventures of surviving the hell that is The Binding of Isaac.
It's a Zelda Roguelike with a highly interpretable Dark Souls esque story. 9.5/10, only thing keeping it down is that it's terribly laggy and suffers other problems from being written in Flash.

When I first heard about this game I was turned off and paid it no mind for quite a while, but when I decided to actually try it, I found that I had no idea what I was missing out on. This game has a interesting gameplay system which has you shooting enemies with your infinite tears and trying your best to escape the horrors around you only to find it gets worse, but not without getting a little tougher yourself... The replayability in this game is through the roof, what with trying to find all the of the items, such as extra max health or accumulating an impenetrable ring of flies. There are also many possible endings. The major drawback I found is that once you start a game it must be done in one sitting; there is no saving and resuming later, and even a quick save would have improved this greatly for me. I give the main game a score of: 8.25/10

The Binding of Isaac is, at first glance, is disgusting, and at times a little silly, but undeniably fun. If you played Two sessions as Issac, that might be the end of it. But give this game a little time, a little effort, and you'll start to see the real depth that lies within. The Binding of Issac does proceedurally generated dungeons right: The room you enter may not always be a challenge, but depending on what items you have at the time, and what transpires after you take a mystery pill, or make a deal with the devil, can compleately change the the flow of gameplay and sometimes, ruin your chance at victory (I speak from experience). The Binding of Issac is one of a handful of games of our generation that is inherantly fun; Playing it is just, fun. It doesn't matter if you win or lose, if you find the one item you so desprately need or not, at some point, none of that matters anyore, and I find myself saying 'I didn't win, but I had fun getting to where I died'. And when you look back at the death skreen filled with every item you've collected, you see the choices you made, or how close you came and it inspires you for next time, because every game starts with a blank room, reminding you of your controls, and every run hold potential for greatness.  Tight, responsive controls that are easy to learn and binded well. Graphics are crisp, but can easily be sacrificed for less lag via a menu. I play this smoothly on a low graphics setting on my laptop, so it's a game you can always have with you if you so choose. I have only sunken 80 some hours into this game but I wish it was more. Do yourself a favor: If your a fan of permadeath, and proceeduraly generated games and pick this up as soon as you can.

Very endearing game. It took me quite a few attempts to finally complete a playthrough. With permadeath and no saves, this was frustrating at times. It's strange though, because part of me was actually a little bit glad every time I died. Because it meant that I'd have to start over and enjoy this game for even longer.  The replay value is great because of the random generator (items/enemies/map layouts), granting a different experience each time. I still come across new items every time I play, and I've played 18 times by this point. I recommend playing in windowed mode with an internet browser open to the The Binding If Isaac 'items' wiki page. You'll thank me XD  The atmosphere is dark and lively, and really sucks you into its world. I enjoyed strategizing and deciding which weapons and items to use, trying to find the most effective combo for my playstyle. This game has a lot more depth than you'd think. It's honestly the most fun I've had with a single player game in a while.

To start I'd like to say that this (with or without DLC) is very much worth your money. It's $4.99 regularly for the bare-bones game. On its own it's good, but with Wrath of the Lamb expansion (still under $10 total) the game is infinitely better. Think of how Brave New World completed Sid Meier's Civilization V, except for an indie video game about crying children who are tortured and made to suffer due to a religious radical who is quite possibly schizophrenic. Regardless, you're in for a good time.  This is probably my favorite piece by McMillen even after the release of Rebirth (not that it isn't a great game as well.) Mind you I haven't seen Super Meat Boy, but I've seen the trailer and it doesn't have the same appeal as this. I have Wrath of the Lamb and it really completes the game with the new collectibles and items as well as the new character. The premise is simple enough and the story is open to speculation. Little is confirmed by the creator.   From my favorite example of It Lives being Isaac as a fetus, it doesn't disprove any major theories and is a decent contribution to many of them.   One of my favorite things about McMillen is that he does allow his fans and users to follow their own thoughts while going through his work.  And now for the actual reviewing part. Gameplay is decent. It's confirmed to be based on Legend of Zelda games in how the 'dungeon' operates. It's randomly generated and each playthrough has different maps that need to be discovered along the way. Occasionally generation or a map will be different, but for the most part it's the same. Each floor has a guarantee of specific rooms spawns with a boss to reach the next floor.  Controls were always strange to me. This game requires no mouse. It's all in the keyboard, which I appreciate as a trackpad user. Cardinal movement is controlled by WASD while the direction of shots is based on the arrow keys by default. Items are used by the convenient spacebar and bombs are dropped with E, which I find better with my preferred configuration. McMillen did include an option for 'lefty flip' which reverses the WASD and arrow keys. This is my preferred configuration even though I am right-handed. The E bomb drop is also more convenient as all attacking items (save for certain spacebar items) can be controlled with the left hand.  Music is unique for each type of level. Sound effects are generic but each type of monster is recognizeable enough that you don't struggle to find out what you're facing in the room. It's nothing spectacular but nothing is bad either.  Some people say the game is difficult. I would agree that it is, but after awhile the game is fairly easily mastered. So long as you pay attention to how each monster attacks and react accordingly you should be fine. The no damage achievements are still difficult, though. The game also has an involuntary difficulty boost after beating one of the many 'final' bosses a certain number of times as well. Considering the amount of experience it takes to unlock that event I'd say it doesn't detract from the game.  As you progress further, the game adds new levels and bosses previously accessible as well as bits and pieces of story here and there. Considering many items are unlocked by achievements obtained over multiple playthroughs this game has a huge amount of replayability. Prior to buying it myself I frequently played on a friend's version and I loved it enough to buy it myself when I finally got my own laptop. Unfortunately I haven't played as much, but it's a great game to fall back on when nothing else is appealing at the moment.  Overall this game is fantastic. There are many pros (controls, story, creativity in bosses and items) to few cons (no voluntary upgrades, some luck-based aspects beyond gambling such as the contents of treasure rooms.) The cons are ultimately outweighed by replayability and how well the game ages in a library. I'll give this a 9/10 would recommend.

I think this game can best be described as a roguelike retooled as a casual game. Not casual in the 'Cawwadoody is for casuals!' sense, casual like Tetris: challenging but addictive and meant to be played in short bursts. It's not a game you play hoping to win; it's a game you pick up because you're bored and feel like shooting some dudes. You can quit whenever you're tired of losing, and pick it up again when you feel like shooting some more dudes. Going up against the same enemies and learning what powerups do what means you gradually get better, while the randomization and the new items you keep unlocking keep it from feeling repetitive.

If there's one thing I need to get back into, it's game reviews.  Let me sum it up like this: If you like Zelda for the NES, you'll love this. If you like randomized gameplay, you'll like this. If you like long games meant to be played once, you may be looking at the wrong game here.  Isaac, to my surprise, was based on beating the game as fast as you can and as many times as you can. As you play, you unlock new items and characters to spice up the next playthrough. If you die, you lose it all and start over.  Still haven't beat it, but I've been playing this game to hell lately and would therefore say it's worth the five dollars. (Seriously, you can buy anything on the McDonald's menu for that price, you're not losing much if you don't like it.) I have't personally played the remake, but from what I've heard, this game is far inferior to it. Either way, five bucks is a good deal, go for it anyways.

I've played almost 100 hours, and while it definitely has a lot of content I can't recommend it. You will ROUTINELY die because Isaac gets caught on the invisible corners of blocks or on scenery. If you don't decide what to do fast enough, enemies can box you in on either side, placing you in a completely unwinnable situation. It's actually possible to arrive on a floor with a locked item room and NO key will spawn anywhere in the level. Roguelike is one thing, but this is just artificially difficult with unwinnable scenarios hardbaked into the game. Until they fix how utterly unfair the RNG is, I can't in good conscience reccomend this to anyone.  However, the music is still very good and the sheer amount of different items allows for almost completely unique experiences every time. It's a shame it's hampered by abysmal floaty controls.

When Isaac’s mom hears a voice from heaven instructing her to kill her son, he flees into the basement to face the horrors within. This is The Binding of Isaac. Note that this is the OG Isaac. The remake, Binding of Isaac Rebirth, is also available on Steam and has numerous improvements to the original Flash-based game. But I don’t own that, so I’m reviewing the original.  Lead Isaac (or one of his unlockable doppelgangers) on a dungeon-crawling adventure. The levels are laid out in the style of The Legend of Zelda, each screen being a room connected by doors. Kill all the enemies in each room to progress to the next. Sometimes you’ll find items that Isaac can attach to his body to make himself stronger, allowing you to take on the tougher challenges deeper in the basement depths. Unlike Zelda, this game is not based primarily on melee combat. This is a ranged twin-stick shooter style game. Your primary weapon is your tears, which are fired at enemies to damage them.  Everything in this game is random, from the layout, to the enemies on each floor, to the difficulty of each floor, to the items you can find. I did about 60 runs and I only saw about half of the available items. Isaac can gain laser eyes or exploding tears, homing bombs or defensive flies. Each of these will not only change how Isaac looks, but will force you to adapt. Either you learn to use what you’ve been given or you will die. The way Isaac becomes more and more monstrous the further you descend is definitely a metaphor for something.  This makes the game extremely unforgiving. Getting through the first two basement levels is easy enough, but without a good set of items that synergize well, you’ll be hard-pressed to get much further. And that’s not to mention the scarcity of hearts sometimes. You’ll often go an entire level at half health, just praying that you don’t get hit by a stray projectile.  The UI is obviously based on NES Zelda, and it works very well. I wish that items gave a little bit more description of their effects, even if it was just on the collection page once I had already seen them once. Graphically, the repulsive creatures of blood, urine, poop, and other bodily fluids are drawn as almost-cute cartoons. That weird disconnect serves the game well, keeping it serious but playful at the same time. This is some dark and twisted stuff, but you can strap a unicorn horn to your head and pop enemies like balloons.  I really liked the music in this, the original version. The updated soundtrack in Rebirth is also good in its own right, but give me the choice between them and I’ll take the old one. The gothic rock soundtrack pumped me up and helped my fingers to move that little bit faster in order to prove myself and get just a little bit further. This game almost never ends. Once you’ve beaten it, it turns out there’s additional chapters after that. And then you can go through it with every unlockable character, who each have their own quirks. And there are 10 challenge modes to tackle. And secret items and rooms to discover only after doing all these other things! In about 12 hours, I was able to beat the first “end” boss only once.  It took me 61 runs to finally finish, and I got really used to seeing that death screen. But the game never felt unfair, even with its total randomization and the way it seemed to stack the deck against me sometimes. It still felt possible to win on each run, and that is what’s key to a game like this. The gameplay is tight, and if you have enough skill you can overcome anything the RNG throws your way.  I would avoid installing the Wrath of the Lamb DLC right away, as that adds a whole load of complexity and difficulty on top of the main game. None of it is readily explained, but most of the new enemies and dungeon layouts are much more difficult and will make quick work of a new player. If you enjoy the original game a lot, then go ahead and expand your experience with those new challenges. Seriously, don’t start out with it.  This is one of the most successful indie games of the past few years, and it has a strong following. If you’re looking for a game to play long-term, where your twitchy reactions are just as important as your perseverance, one that never runs out of new goals for you to achieve, this might be the one for you.

This game is a masterpiece. You play as a baby that kills everything, crawls up his moms vijayjay, and cries at his unborn brother. It has great replay value with tons of items that give the player many quirky abilities and trying to complete the collection is an addictive objective. The mission is to find the most broken combo. It has the perfect balance of luck and skill with the need to ajust your play style with the random items that you find. The challenges are the random trash items, persistent enemies that will just throw themselves at you in enormous groups, some of the outragous and seemingly unfair bosses, and the limited one use items. You beat all these incredibly hard enemies and survive in very difficult situations just to get killed by a fly/spider/your own bomb. Sometimes it will make you want to throw your computer out a window and cry for hours but then it will fill you with determination and the power needed to surpass your past achievements. Perfect for people that want to learn about Christianity but are too lazy to read the bible. I r8 8/8.

The premise is simple: you walk through a dungeon and kill monsters by crying at them, becoming a monster yourself as you pick up various upgrades they drop (or you buy or find). However, the game suffers from its randomly generated dungeons, which seem to have very few guidelines and often result in a wide spread of difficulty, not to mention making the loot unatainable 25% of the time. Furthermore, you have no idea what an upgrade will do until you use it, and that information is saved only for that game, meaning that you start over every single time you play. I get the idea of providing a different experience each time you play, but there need to be rules.

Well, you're either going to find the style humorous or just plain wrong to the point that you can't play. If you're in the first group, you'll find a zelda-like rogue game from half the folks that brought you Super Meat Boy. It's not nearly as punishingly difficult as the boy of meat's adventure, though still more difficult than typical of modern games. The gameplay definitely strikes a one-more-game chord. I highly recommend looking up joy to key, like the devs recommend, and plugging in a gamepad. Wish that option was native, but the game was coded for a version of Flash that doesn't support pads or even GPU acceleration. It has since been coded in a different language, but the support wasn't added. 4/5

This is a very weird game, but its weird in a good way. Heres a quick explanation; Your a kid named Isaac who lives a peacefull life together with your mom, but one day your mom thinks she heard a voice from above. It was God and he told her to sacrafice you in his honnor, so as an atempt to escape you jump into the basement trough a trapdoor under your rug. Your goal is to go through the basement to find your mom and kill her before she kills you. Ist a basic shoot-em up with basic controls, but the game is far from easy. Through evry stage of the basement there is a randomly shoosen mini-boss to deafiete, your only attack from the start is your tears which you blast at your enemies and you need to pick up power-ups so that you dont die of underpowerness. Its a really hard game, and if you have some money to spend i should recomend to you, and you who wants a great challenge and a great blast.
